Site_context_name: Late Bronze Age / Early Iron Age funerary, domestic, and agricultural landscapes, Saltwood
Site_context_summary: Late Bronze Age / Early Iron Age funerary, domestic, and agricultural landscapes, Saltwood
Site_context_description: Excavations carried out between 1998-2001 at the Saltwood Tunnel and Stone Farm Bridleway sites, by Canterbury Archaeology Trust and Wessex Archaeology, as part of the CTRL works.Late Bronze Age / Early Iron Age funary, domestic, and agricultural landscapes.An area around the eastern-most Early Bronze Age barrow (TR 13 NE 214) (one of the two larger barrows) appears to have been utilised as a funerary environment. A small sub-square enclosure lies to the east of the barrow, orientated with the adjacent field system, and is associated with features containing cremated bone. A cremation lies within, but is stratigraphically earlier than, the enclosure and is not central within the enclosure. A single cremation lies 250m to the SW (not associated with a barrow), with a further 5 confirmed and 2 possible cremations within and around the large barrow to the west. These later 7 cremations are spatially dated, but could date to the Late Iron Age / Early Roman period due their location next to a trackway (TR 13 NE 220) of that date.Settlement is focused around one or two partially identified sub-rectangular enclosures in the centre of the excavated area. The enclosures appear to be delimited by both ditches and a small section of a post line, though the relative dating is unknown. A large number of post-holes to the west of one of the enclosures may represent a series of fence-lines or small structures, though the form of any is unclear. They could represent the western side of an enclosure, the exact line of which varied over time. Additional ditches suggest a field system, which respects the position of the earlier barrows. A number of pits with cinder-capping were noted (the cinder-capping acting as an odour plug on refuge pits). Additional pits and post-holes suggest a settlement focus. It is possible that the trackways (TR 13 NE 220) that are more prominent in later phases have their origins in this phase. (1)Additional bibliography. (2-3)

Site_context_name: Iron Age site, St. Stephen's College site, North Foreland
Site_context_summary: An Early Iron Age to Middle Iron Age enclosure with possible occupation into the Late Iron Age.
Site_context_description: In 1999 the Trust for Thanet Archaeology carried out an evaluation of the St. Stephen's College site. Several pits were found containing Early Iron Age and Late Iron Age pottery. A possible palisade trench was also found but did not contain any datable material. The Early Iron Age pottery was largely described as residual with most of the features dated by the Late Iron Age sherds, i.e. 150-50 BC. Despite this, it is likely that there was Early Iron Age occupation in the area dating to c.550-350 BC. (1)A joint excavation by Canterbury Archaeological Trust and the Trust for Thanet Archaeology following an evaluation and an initial strip and map phase. The final phase of excavation work was carried out by the Trust for Thanet Archaeology alone. All the work was carried out in 1999.From the Early Iron Age there was an enclosure on the site. Several possible four post structures were located within the enclosure. A number of pits were also dug during this occupation. Activity continued through the Middle Iron Age and possibly into the Late Iron Age. Material from the Late Iron Age was found in the upper fills of many older features, though some pits were located in the same area as the Early and Middle Iron Age pits, suggesting some possible continuation of occupation on the site. (2)In 2003 the land to the south was excavated by the Trust for Thanet Archaeology. The southern half of the enclosure ditch was located along with a scatter of features to the south, east and west of this. The ditch itself appears to have been dug in the Middle Iron Age. Disarticulated human bones were found within it, along with disturbed earlier material suggesting site clearance in the Late Iron Age. Other features of Early to Middle Iron Age date included large storage pits, some of which contained human remains. An adult female had been buried in one and the disarticulated remains of a neonate were found in a second. A further crouched inhumation of an adult female was found with Early to Middle Iron Age pottery. A number of pit or post alignments were found, one of which had disturbed the burial.The Late Iron Age saw further pit or post hole alignments created. Two ditches were dug at this time, one shorter and the other a boundary ditch dug across the site (it was also encountered on the site to the north). Disarticulated human bones (male and female, adult, young adult and neonate) were found in both features. A pit group dated to this period also contained disarticulated human ribs. Only three early Roman features were found, suggesting the site had gone out of use in the Late Iron Age. (3)

Site_context_name: Iron Age boundary ditch, Downs Road
Site_context_summary: A large ditch, probably with a bank to the west of it. The partially filled ditch was the focus for a number of later inhumations.
Site_context_description: In 2006 Oxford Archaeology carried out work at the site. A large boundary ditch which probably had a bank to the west of it. The earliest silting of the ditch contained Middle Iron Age pottery. Subsequently the ditch was partially filled, possibly with material from the slighting of the bank. Two inhumation burials were dug into this material. These were of an adult and an infant. An additional inhumation was placed in the southern terminal of the ditch, in a coffin, and was associated with a mid 1st century vessel. The ditch finally silted in the Roman period. A crouched inhumation of a 11-13 year old child was found nearby but was undated. A number of Middle Iron Age gullies and pits were also recorded in the area. One pit contained a cow skull and what are likely to be instances of structured deposition. The bank may have survived as a feature for some considerable time as later features appear to respect the likely area it would have occupied. (1)

Site_context_name: Late Iron Age enclosed settlement, Northumberland Bottom
Site_context_summary: An enclosed settlement was established in the Late Iron Age between Downs Road and Wrotham Road dry valleys on the west-facing hillside. The site continued in use into the Roman period, reaching its height in the late 1st century AD.
Site_context_description: In 1998 Museum of London Archaeology Service carried out an excavation as part of the Channel Tunnel Rail Link project. An enclosed settlement was established between Downs Road and Wrotham Road dry valleys on the west-facing hillside. The site continued in use into the Roman period, reaching its height in the late 1st century AD.The earliest phase of activity related to a hollow way with a ditch and bank that could have been of Middle Iron Age date. In the Late Iron Age, an enclosure was laid out to the east of the hollow way. The earliest use of this may have been livestock related as there were no traces of domestic activity. The enclosure was subsequently enlarged, putting the hollow way out of use. Within this larger enclosure, there were a number of pits, ovens or kilns a possible hearth and two burials. One was cremation in a pedestal urn in a small pit on the east side of the enclosure. A copper alloy open ring was found within it. Disarticulated human remains of at least two individuals were found in a pit near the entrance on the north side of the enclosure. The pit also contained two fragments of loomweights and a Colchester type one-piece bow brooch. The pit was filled by the end of the 1st century AD. A horse burial was found on the west side of the enclosure. The animal had been 11-15.5 years old, 1.4-149m high (14-14 1/2 hands) with signs of traction and riding stresses. (1-3)

Site_context_name: Late Iron Age/early Roman ditches and cremations, 75 The Street, Hawkinge
Site_context_summary: Late Iron Age/early Roman ditches and later cremations of the 1st century AD.
Site_context_description: In 2006 Archaeology South-East carried out an evaluation and an excavation. Three ditches crossing the site were dated to the Late Iron Age/early Roman period. The site was subsequently used for cremation burials. Four such burials were found in the south east corner of the site, three had accompanying vessels and one was a single urned cremation. (1)

Site_context_name: Early Bronze Age activity, Springhead
Site_context_summary: Early Bronze Age activity was found across part of the site in the form of Beaker and Collared Urn fragments but also two small clusters of pits and a variety of other features.
Site_context_description: In 2007/8 Wessex Archaeology carried out a programme of works. An area of the site contained a number of Early Bronze Age features, with material of this date also recovered from later features in the same area. Two small clusters of Beaker pits were found. Material from these pits included grain and weed seeds, a large number of worked flints, including 34 scrapers from one pit and sherds of pottery. Flintworking debris had been dumped in the pits, one pit contained an arrowhead roughout. Flints were refitted from different pits, suggesting that the pits had been open at the same time and received dumps of material from the same source. One of the pits had flints placed against the edges of the pit, presumably deliberately. Another possibly deliberately placed deposit was found at the base of a pit, consisting of a set of tools - four end-scrapers, two backed knives, a broken blade and a hammerstone, with sherds of pottery. This was all associated with a large quantity of hazelnuts. Other features included three post holes in a triangular arrangement and clay-lined pits. Parts of a field system (TQ 67 SW 1356) may have been established in this period. A number of the ditches had Late Neolithic/Early Bronze Age objects in basal fills or in termini. An un-urned cremation burial was also found, it was dated to this period on the basis of proximity to other features. (1)

Site_context_name: Bronze Age field system, Springhead
Site_context_summary: A Middle and Late Bronze Age field system, plus pits (some of which contained possible ritual deposits) and un-urned cremations.
Site_context_description: In 2007/8 Wessex Archaeology carried out a programme of works. A Bronze Age field system was laid out across the area. Elements of the system may have been created in the Early Bronze Age (see TQ 67 SW 1355) but the full system was of Middle and Late Bronze Age date. A droveway was associated with the system and continued in use possibly into the Roman period. Post holes of a possible fenceline were sealed below Bronze Age colluvium. The fence was on the same alignment as the field system. There were no traces of structures found but a number of pits were scattered across the site, perhaps indicating some form of domestic occupation of the area. Many of these were clay lined, as the Early Bronze Age pits had been. One pit contained an inverted Deverel-Rimbury vessel, along with two scrapers and a blade. Another pit had two vessels, one within another. No cremated remains were found with these and one pit may have originally had a domed structure sealing it. These may therefore have been placed deposits of some ritual function. These were not the only form of structured deposition found on the site; the terminal of one of the field ditches contained a concentration of finds that may have been a placed deposit. Numerous Late Bronze Age-Early Iron Age sherds, particularly deliberately broken rim sherds, were found. A partially articulated buzzard was also found in this deposit. A number of un-urned cremations and features with cremation related deposits within them were found across the site. These are prehistoric in date and perhaps of this particular phase of activity. (1)An evaluation by Wessex Archaeology in 2008 to the north of the area excavated in 2007/8 found the ditches of the field system. (2)In 2012 Wessex Archaeology carried out a strip, map and sample excavation on the North Kent Community Church site to the north of the 2007/8 work. Ditches of the field system were found to continue across the site. (3)

Site_context_name: Middle Bronze Age/Late Bronze Age cremation cemetery, Highstead Farm
Site_context_summary: A platform, possibly a pyre site, and a scatter of grouped and isolated pits, possibly representing urned cremations and pyre deposits.
Site_context_description: In 2001 Archaeology South-East carried out an excavation. An extensive Middle Bronze Age to Late Bronze Age cremation cemetery was found. A sub-circular platform was located on the eastern part of the site. It was c.10m x8m and was formed by the cutting of a complex series of curving ditches. Burnt material was found in the ditches along with large quantities of Late Bronze Age pottery and a small quantity of Middle Bronze Age pottery.  There was a rectangular pit located in the centre of the platform, again containing burnt material and Middle Bronze Age pottery. Seven post holes were found around the area. Gullies to the north possibly represented an entranceway. The platform may have been a pyre site and/or a ploughed out barrow. Two possible pyre deposits, one potentially an urned cremation, were found nearby.Across the central part of the site, at least 43 possible cremations/pyre deposits were found. Several contained pottery sherds and these could have derived from burial containers. The deposits were found in both isolated positions and in discrete groups. A number of possible pyre sites were found, some associated with clusters of burials. A Middle Bronze Age/Late Bronze Age ditch possibly enclosed part of the site. (1)

Site_context_name: Middle Bronze Age cremation cemetery, Manston Road, Ramsgate
Site_context_summary: A Middle Bronze Age cremation cemetery, consisting of six unurned cremation burials and a pit with a vessel deposited with burnt material.
Site_context_description: In 2007-8 Archaeology South-East carried out a strip, map and sample excavation of the site. A small Middle Bronze Age cremation cemetery was found in the northern part of the site. Six unurned cremations were found in a group (with one outlier). No finds or pottery were associated with any of the cremations. Also dating to this period was a small pit containing a near complete possibly miniature plain globular pot. This deposit was thought to possibly relate to the cremation cemetery given the presence of burnt material. Radiocarbon dating for the cremations and the vessel deposit were all in the Middle Bronze Age. (1)

Site_context_name: Iron Age settlement and inhumations, Seacroft Road, Dumpton Gap
Site_context_summary: Excavation of an Iron Age settlement site by T.C. Champion in 1971-2 revealed two pits containing inhumations.
Site_context_description: Excavation of an Iron Age settlement site by T.C. Champion in 1971-2 revealed two pits containing inhumations. (1)Fragments of Late Bronze Age/Early Iron Age pottery were found in a gully or palisade trench. This feature was cut by pits containing Early Iron Age pottery. Two or three phases of activity were evident on the site. The site appears to have continued into the Middle Iron Age but there is little evidence for later activity. (2)

Site_context_name: Bronze Age to early iron age activity, Ebbsfleet Farm Cottages
Site_context_summary: During the East Kent Access Route excavations a number of bronze age to early iron age features were discovered. These suggested a pattern of field boundaries and enclosures that changed alignment in the later bronze age from east-west to north-east south-west. Pits, a well, a cremation and metalworking evidence all suggest the presence of a settlement in the vicinity.
Site_context_description: During the East Kent Access Route excavations a number of bronze age to early iron age features were discovered (phases 2 - 4). These suggested a pattern of field boundaries and enclosures that changed alignment in the later bronze age from east-west to north-east south-west. Pits, enclosures, metalled surfaces, a well, a cremation in a collared urn and metalworking evidence all suggest the presence of a settlement in the vicinity.  A shield binding was also found from a late iron age context.Phase 3c in particular contained remains of a early to middle iron age settlement. A series of domestic enclosures and droveways were created. There were several groups of pits and postholes containing domestic waste, loomweights and quernstones. There were at least 5 discrete enclosures, each containing domestic remains such as pits, postholes, fences, round-houses and  four-post structures which were probably grain stores .As with zones 4 and 7 of the East Kent Access excavations evidence was found of the enclosure of the neck of the peninsula by an iron age ditch that was later recut during the Roman period (dated by pottery finds) , possibly with a military function (based on the 'V'shape of the Roman recut). Other finds were recovered from the early Roman period including a post-Claudian Nauheim brooch and a Colchester fibula. Once the Roman ditch was cut there was a general decline in the intensity of the use of this area with no further round houses. By the middle Roman period the pattern of enclosures and ditches had almost completely disappeared. Two sunken-features buildings were instead constructed, one close to a small cemetery on the western limit of the excavation. The building itself went out of use and an oven was constructed in the hollow. (1)

Site_context_name: Late Iron Age-Roman Activity at Thanet Earth
Site_context_summary: Late Iron Age -Roman features, including ditches and cremation burials were observed in an evaluation in 2007 and 2008.
Site_context_description: An archaeological evaluation took place in 2007 and 2008 on the site which is now Thanet Earth. Generally, finds of this period were sparse compared with some of the other periods. There did not seem to be any concentration of activity sucah as a settlement. At least three separate hollow ways, extending across the site from east to west, one curving to the north_east, were in use during the Roman period, but almost certainly originated as routes before, probably in the Iron Age. Small groups of cremation burials were associated with one of these trackways, as was a single Roman structure. Two phases of rectilinear field system defined by ditches were also located, the earlier probably originating in the late Iron Age. Two small square enclosures were located that wereassociated with the earlier field system. Enclosure 10 contained three cremation burials (G8162, two of which were quite richly furnished box burials) suggesting that it was a mortuary enclosure. At least some of the burials may be related to the only definite Roman structure located on the site (SFB 1) which consisted of an isolated sunken_featured structure, similar in some ways to others previously found on Thanet, but otherwise unique. Other remains included a number of quarries and isolated pits mostly situated in the northern half of the Thanet Earth site; this concentration of remains, steadily diminishing towards the southern higher areas, is a facet of the feature distribution as a whole. (1)

Site_context_summary: Large La Tene square barrow cemetery originally having over 100 small barrows the majority of which have been levelled by cultivation. Many of the barrows have been excavated, including three which contained cart burials.
Site_context_description: Arras Iron Age Barrow Cemetery, _ m. south-west of Arras and bisected by the A1079. Originally there were over a hundred small round barrows, 8-30ft in diameter, and 1-3ft high, in this cemetery, although the majority have since been levelled by cultivation. The majority of barrows covered simple inhumations accompanied by bronze brooches, armlets and beads. Three of the burials were probably those of chieftains (one a women), as they were more richly furnished and contained the dismantled remains of chariots and horse harness and in one case the skeletons of the two ponies which had pulled the vehicle. <1> A large Iron Age cemetery lying in the vicinity of Arras and Hessleskew farms comprised at least 100 or 200 small barrows, many of which were opened in 1815-17 by E.W.Stillingfleet and B.Clarkson. Dr.Hull of Beverley also appears to have been involved at about this time. Three more were opened by the Yorkshire Antiquarian Club in 1850. Site_context_description: CDG added. Long barrow reused as round barrow? Oriented E-W and 42m long x 12m wide and 1.4m high. Approximate site of two long Barrows, Greenwell No 66.. Earth in the middle and chalk on either side; to the W. end there seemed to be a round barrow, in it an adult female burial with an "A" Beaker. Above this was a skeleton of a child, below the woman lay a wooden beam 5'9" x 9" x 4" covering a 7ft grave in which was a skeleton & "C" Beaker, and bones, of a skeleton which had been relaid after disturbance. 76ft. E. of grave were further human skeletons of a man and two children. A second mound 190ft long, 50ft wide 4ft high extended from W. end of the first. No burial found in it, but flint flakes, charcoal and pottery fragments were numerous. Animal bones, and plain dark coloured pottery Neo 'A' according to Newbigin P.P.5.3., this includes a rim of Form H and a horizontal lug. This is one of two pairs of Long Barrows at Rudston joined in V formation. The other pair form Greenwell's No 224. he principle mound was aligned east-west, with either of the two extremities being of a greater elevation than the middle part. The mound was 137 ft long with a mean breadth of 40ft, the west end was 4.5ft high and the east 5ft. The long barrow contained numerous animal bones, flint chippings, charcoal and sherds of plain, dark-coloured pottery throughout the whole of its length but principally at the level of the old ground surface. At the west end and below the centre of the round barow was the body of a young adult women. The inhumation was 2ft above the level of the natural surface and just in front of the right tibia was a "drinking cup". At a level 6" higher (the head lying above the woman's knees) were the remains of a child aged about 8 or 9. Immediately above the head was a flint knife 1.75" long. Underneath the woman, at the level of the natural surface, was a wooden beam which covered a grave which was 7ft long, 4.5ft wide and 2ft deep. This grave contained the body of an adult of uncertain sex, behind the head was a "drinking cup" , three flint scrapers and some chippings were also found in the grave. Just beyond the feet of this inhumation were the remains of a young woman which had been disturbed and relaid. They had been placed in a heap with the skull on top of the other bones. The mound also contained the remains of a male of large stature, a child and a single piece of burnt bone.

Site_context_name: Grimthorpe, Millington
Site_context_summary: E 815 533) An Iron Age univallate hill fort almost levelled by the plough was identified in AP's in 1958 (2). It had formerly been noted by Mortimer (1) who mentions the "filled up inner ditch of a supposed camp" in describing a burial discovered in a chalkpit within the 'camp' in 1868. The burial was associated with an iron sword, shield, spearhead etc. (Finds in the BM) Three other inhumations were unaccompanied. A trial excavation was carried out in 1958 followed by further excavations in 1961/2.The defences consisted of a single ditch 6-7 feet deep, 10-15 feet wide, with a berm on the inside 12 to 15 feet wide, behind that a timber laced bank 6 feet wide, and an entrance in the SE; enclosing approx 8 acres. Site_context_summary: Site of a Roman Auxiliary Fort, identified on aerial photographs and through trial excavation. Site_context_description: SE 816 454. Roman auxiliary fort of 3_ acres discovered by J.K St Joseph (A.P's BQQ 9 and 10) at SE 816 454, Hayton parish. The aerial photographs taken by St. Joseph in 1974 show a small fort surrounded by double ditches, distinct on the south-east, north-east and north-west sides, with rounded angles. Further photography in 1975 introduced the possibility that the fort had a single-ditched annexe to the north-east. A small scale excavation in Febuary 1975 located the eastern angle, parts of the angle-tower and the south-east gateway. In October and November 1975 further excavations took place on the north side of the road and located the line of the ditches on the three remaining sides as well as the north-east gateway, the north angle-tower and remains of two of the interior buildings. The fort was found to be a regular rectangle measuring 148 metres north-east and south-west by 101 metres. There were two defensive ditches in all the areas examined. The outer ditch was V-shaped, 2.2m wide and 1.0m deep. The inner ditch was a shallow U-shape, 3.8m wide and 1.0m deep. There was no surviving trace of the rampart, its position being indicated only by that of the post holes of the gate and corner towers. Finds were prolific, especially pottery, but also included coins, animal bones, quern-stones and a number of small finds. Site_context_name: SITE OF WEST FURZE LAKE DWELLING
Site_context_summary: Site of West Furze Lake Dwelling that was excavated in 1880-81 by Boynton and found to have had two periods of occupation, Neolithic and Late Bronze Age/Iron Age.
Site_context_description: Aerial photograph of the site from the NMR. <1> 'The overlying platforms, 72ft east-west by 50ft north-south, of a two period lake dwelling, Neolithic and Late Bronze Age/Iron Age, cut by Skipsea Drain, was discovered and excavated 1880-81 by Boynton. The adjacent area had Iron Age/Romano-British occupation. The platforms lay on a peat layer over natural gravel which is 10ft below modern ground level. The construction was of a layer of brushwood overlain by large tree trunks and branches held together by piles inserted between them. The spaces were filled in with broken wood, the whole covered by a layer of sand and then 18ins of twigs and bark. On the north side were two straight rows of blunt pointed stakes, probably connecting both shores, with a single row at south facing upstream. The earliest occupation was characterized by piles sharpened by stone tools and the absence of pottery. The later occupation showed that the platform was extended beyond its earlier limits and the piles had been sharpened with metal tools. Associated with this occupation was a bronze socketed spearhead and pottery. Three human skulls were found at the eastern end of the excavated area, one being recognised as of Bronze Age type. Other finds from the platform included bone and antler tools, flint scrapers, hammer-stones, stone rubber, animal bones both wild and domestic, winged axe etc. About 20 yards south-east of the lake dwelling was a pit, 30ft long by 8ft wide, containing an Iron Age urn, height 26ins maximum circumference 6ft, now in British Museum; human skeletal remains, including skull; at higher level Roman pottery, including base of moratorium; 15ins to 18ins from top Medieval pottery. The nucleus of a network of ditches, some of which enclose a group of Iron Age type square ditched barrows, on AP's are TA 149 566 (Possibly associated with Iron Age phase of lake dwelling). At the time of the visit this site was under pasture and nothing was seen. Site_context_name: GARTON STATION BARROW CEMETERY
Site_context_summary: Aerial photographs show cropmarks of an Iron Age square barrow cemetery, with Anglo-Saxon burials, partially excavated in  1985.
Site_context_description: Aerial photographs show three areas of mainly square barrows. Those barrows along with two square enclosures, at SE 982 578 were excavated in 1985. Interpretation of aerial photograph made by R.Teal in 1991. <1> Information sheet from Humberside Archaeological Unit concerning the Excavations at Garton on the Wolds in 1985, No.8 <2> Photocopied extract from 'New Light On The Parisi', by P.Halkon, 1989, p.1-6. <3> Aerial photographs showing the square barrow cemetery along with various other features, including ring ditch, round barrow and dyke. <4> Excavation summary from I.M.Stead, 'Iron Age Cemeteries in East Yorkshire' p.17-24, figs 16-22. <5> Aerial photograph showing a possible area of square barrows, some with central pits, centred at SE 972 584. <6> An excavation directed by I.M.Stead for the British Museum discovered a chariot burial in a grave 4.0m by 2.4m and 1.4m deep, orientated north-south, at the centre of a barrow 11-12 square. The wheels had been stacked leaning against the side of the grave, their decayed wooden naves and spokes replaced in clay. The pole and axle had been buried as a single T-shaped frame, 3.0m long and 2.2m across. The flexed corpse had been buried first and the framework of the vehicle lowered on top of it. The line of the yoke placed behind the body could be distinguished by a row of five terrets, the central one being finely decorated in relief. Alongside was a pair of linch pins and two horse pits; animal bones lay in front of and behind the shoulders of the body. A box shape, 1.7m by 1.0m, traced by darker filling above the skelton, may be the body of the chariot, upturned to cover it. Five smaller square barrows each had an unaccompanied north-south crouched burial in a large and deep grave. Four similar-sized barrows within ring ditches, two having causeways, had unusual features. The burials of males, one with a sword, another with a shield, all had iron spear or javelin heads thrust or thrown into the grave, 14 in that with a sword, and 11,7 and 3 in the others. Comparable finds have been made at Burton Fleming, Wetwang Slack and Grimthorpe. An enclosure 16-18m square with an entrance to the west is unique. No Iron Age grave was found within it but its centre was occupied by two rows of Anglian burials. Three other square barrows to the north-east, also had a western entrance and one had an extended east-west inhumation with a spearhead, but with an Anglian shield handle near the left hand. See also Current Archaeology 9 (1987), 234-7 and Anglo-Scandinavian Section. During excavations by I.M Stead thirty-five Anglian inhumation burials were discovered both at the centre of a large Iron Age enclosure, in three other Iron Age barrows, and elsewhere. Most were orientated east-west and grave goods indicate a 7th century date. A young child was accompanied by a fine gold pendant with filigree ornament, a silver toilet set, three silver rings and glass beads; a woman was buried with a brooch, pendant, bead and buckle, all of silver. A fine decorated hanging bowl had been missed by grave robbers. Other unusual graves included one with a bronze cauldron and support, and another with an iron ladle and a possible socketed weaving baton. Weapons were found in five graves and tools in two, knives came from eighteen and buckles from twelve graves. Bronze staples and iron fittings indicated wooden boxes or leather bags. Animal bones were found with twelve burials, usually at the feet. These burials were apparently an extension of Mortimer's Garton Gatehouse cemetery 500m to the east. Site_context_name: Iron Age and Romano-British occupation at Quarry Lodden, Bincombe
Site_context_summary: During construction of a gas pipeline in 1971 a deep layer of black soil, several pits and a number of crouched burials were seen by E Flatters. Subsequently a small excavation was carried out at the point where occupation seemed most dense. Several levels of floor interspersed with layers containing occupation debris, a pit and hearths were recorded. One floor appeared to be made partly of slabs of shale, which the excavators suggested may have been the floor of a narrow passage. Finds included an unfinished shale armlet and a fragment of another, leading to the suggestion that there may at some time have been shale working on the site.
Site_context_description: In 1971 during construction of the trench for a gas pipeline passing east of Dorchester to the eastern end of Came Wood and then south-eastwards across the South Dorset Ridgeway along the spur to the west of Coombe Valley, Eric Flatters noticed an unusual depth of black soil east of Quarry Lodden. He also saw several pits and a number of crouched burials, one with a bowl of the so-called  war cemetery  type seen at Maiden Castle. Subsequently small excavation was carried out at the point where observations of the trench suggested that occupation was most dense. Two trenches 3m long and 1.5m wide were excavated parallel to the pipeline trench and about 5m from it on either side. In due course the northern trench was abandoned, and the southern one extended to a 3m by 3m square. Immediately below the ploughsoil was a small area of a floor constructed of flat stones packed with puddled chalk. No dating evidence was found, but the floor was interpreted as representing the remnants of a later Romano-British level, largely ploughed out.  An accumulation of dark soil overlay a floor of compacted limestone fragments. Pottery in this dark soil was Durotrigian and Romano-British. This floor sealed a pit, the fillings of which contained a little pottery. Below the floor was a partly broken up floor of stone and shale over a thick layer of black earth and stone over another floor of large stone slabs and a hearth of puddled chalk. Three slabs of shale were found, and the excavators speculated that these may have been the floor of a narrow passageway.  The black layer and ash from the hearth contained Iron Age B and early Durotrigian pottery. Below this was a series of alternating hearths with layers of ash, down to a layer over natural limestone. At this level Iron Age A pottery was found, with fabrics and forms comparable to those at Maiden Castle, Pins Knoll and Chalbury. This pottery included heamatite-coated situlate jars and derivative types, in fabric described as hard, occasionally burnished and varying in colour from bright red to dullish brown. Finds from the site included an unfinished shale armlet and a fragment of another, leading to speculation that there may at some time have been shale working on the site.  It is not clear from the report whether any other shale objects or waste were noted. Other finds included worked bone awls and flat pieces of bone, also worked, and a bone implement possibly associated with weaving. An iron stylus and knife blade were found, and a bronze object described as a  fish  by the excavators, but which appears to be a nail cleaner. {1}

Site_context_summary: Iron age and Romano British settlement site and Inhumation burials at was excavated by C E Bean in 1932-39 and Mrs A Williams in 1944-5. An Iron Age settlement, which as then unoccupied from the 1st century until late in the 3rd century when it was reoccupied.

Site_context_name: Portland: Beehive chambers found at Coombefield Quarries, Weston
Site_context_summary: A corbelled beehive chamber was found at Coombefield quarries in 1897, near it was an oblong chamber with rounded corners. Another beehive chamber examined in 1898 had an arched entrance on its N side . Photographs provide evidence of two other beehive chambers found in 1906? And 1907 receptively.
Site_context_description: A number of beehive chambers are recorded at Coombefield Quarries Weston, Portland. The first record is of a corbelled stone beehive chamber discovered in 1897, with a diameter of about 5ft. This chamber is alleged to have contained human remains (4 001 105 B) 2 yards away from it, an oblong chamber with rounded corners was found. It measures 7ft by 4 and a half ft and it was some 3ft high. It lay NNW to SSE, and was walled with Purbeck stone partly corbelled and closed with flat slabs. Within its rubble fill, numerous artefacts were retrieved, including sherds, a hammer-stone, flint flakes, slingstones, charred wood and shells. Another stone-lined beehive chamber , measuring 4 and a half ft high with a diameter of 5ft examined in 1898 had an arched entrance or passage on its N side 8ft long with a circular hole 4 and a half ft deep in its floor. This chamber contained Iron Age pottery, a rough mortar and a pebble pestle. A further two beehive chambers were identified in photographs. One from 1906 shows a corbelled beehive about 4ft in diameter, found empty, the other of a beehive chamber found in 1907 is approximately 4 and three quarter ft in diameter with vertical wall surviving to 4 and a half ft. Site_context_name: Bestwall Quarry Archaeological Project, Field E, Bronze Age cremation cemetery
Site_context_summary: Small late Bronze Age urnfield dated on ceramic evidence. Site consisted of possible field or enclosure boundaries, a circular structure of indeterminate function and a cremation area
Site_context_description: Small late Bronze Age urnfield dated on ceramic evidence, situated on the ridge overlooking the Piddle Valley. Site consisted of possible field or enclosure boundaries, a circular structure of indeterminate function and a cremation area.  The urnfield comprised a baked clay hearth together with nine pits, one containing the base of a bucket urn and another a complete hearthstone quern. Acidic soils are likely to have precluded the survival of any cremated bone . Small quantities of late Bronze Age pottery were recovered from all pits, identified as bucket and globular urns typical of the Deverel Rimbury tradition. To the north an excavated structure, possibly a mortuary enclosure, may be associated with the cemetery.  A shallow circular gully with a diameter of 10.2m was also excavated with internal shallow scoops and possible postholes. Two external postholes may have been part of a porch. A north-south ditch was also excavated, 1.5m wide by 0.8m deep containing late Bronze Age pottery. A second east-west ditch separated the urnfield from the structure to the south. A broken chert blade was present in the fill (1)

Site_context_name: Bestwall Quarry Archaeological Project, Field R, Bronze Age settlement
Site_context_summary: Early Middle and Late Bronze Age phases of Activity identified in Field R
Site_context_description: Early Bronze Age: Two small sherds of Beaker pottery found in a Roman ditch and a single sherd of biconical urn was retrieved from a scoopMiddle Bronze Age: 62 features comprising pits (and charcoal pits see WX3516), scoops, postholes, and one ditch/gully. Two 'special' deposits and five single 'pot' deposits of note and two areas of intense activity observed. One area 13m x 13m included: a shallow sub-circular gully with finds, concentrated to the centre of the ring, suggesting an industrial function; a ring of postholes with a 7m diameter, probably representing a roundhouse, two postholes were capped with a 0.1m layer of raw white clay; an oval pit with pottery from at least three vessels. The other area was 10m x 13m and included: a ring of postholes with an internal pit and three internal postholes that may have been part of an internal dividing structure; a storage pit with raw and fired clay from pottery manufacture and pottery, worked flint, burnt flint, burnt hearthstone, limestone, shale and a few fragments of bone. There was an absence of features in the south and east of the whole excavated area.Late Bronze Age: A cluster of features consisting of pits, scoops and postholes presented no discernible pattern One pit had been lined with large pieces of hearthstone. The fill was rich in charcoal and ash and there was evidence of in situ burning. Pottery fragments, raw and fired clay, charcoal, burnt hearthstone and burnt flint found in many features suggesting industrial activity. A single urned cremation was also found. The charcoal rich pot fill contained human bone, possibly from more than one body (1)

Site_context_name: Metherhills: Shale industry
Site_context_summary: Iron Age/Romano-British shale industry
Site_context_description: Coal Money abundant at Metherhills. (1) In a large pasture between the village of Kimmeridge and the Bay. Lieut. E. Garard Smith found an oval shaped kistvaen containing human remains. A rough ring of Kimmeridge shale was placed on each side of the skull. Site_context_name: Tyneham Gwyle: Shale industry
Site_context_summary: Evidence of Iron Age/Romano British shale industry, Iron Age/Romano-British occupation site including inhumations, briquetage and C1st to C4th pottery. Possible stone working.
Site_context_description: Inhumation burials, and occupation debris, perhaps Iron Age to late Roman, with evidence for shale-working and perhaps Purbeck marble and salt industries, have been found on the cliffs N of Tyneham Gwyle above the 100ft contour and near the Purbeck marble outcrop at Worbarrow Tout. A layer of large stones and many sherds, shale fragments and flint flakes are visible in the cliff face. A layer of stones uncovered in excavations in 1937 was thought to have been a possible foundation for a floor of chalk blocks. Many finds typical of a site of this nature such as pottery, sling stones, spindle whorls and a bronze plaque were found below the layer of stones. Pieces of shale, worn flint flakes, an armlet fragment and 72 cores suggested some form of shale industry whilst a few pieces of briquetage inferred salt-boiling.A coin of Commodus (180-92) was found on the cliffs. Pottery, including Durotrigian types, is mainly 1st and 2nd century with some stray Iron Age A and B sherds. Second century Samian sherds were found, and a similar range of pottery at SY 87118001 included 3rd and 4th century conical flanged bowls. Pottery of that date was also recovered from the stream at SY 87207990. Earlier accounts add little although mention is made of an inhumation burial in a covered stone cist. Another, all or partly of shale, was found in 1908. (1-5)

Site_context_name: Bestwall Quarry Archaeological Project, Fields T, N and Z  Bronze Age cremation, ditches and pits
Site_context_summary: Sections of Bronze Age ditches and pits recorded in Fields T, N and Z during excavations at Bestwall Quarry. A single MBA cremation excavated in Field Z.
Site_context_description: Section of Bronze Age ditches were recorded during excavations at Bestowal Quarry (1)Early Bronze Age: 100m length of ditch aligned SE-NW in Field T - discontinued lengths of this feature recorded in Fields J, E and P. Ditch with a steep sided and flat-based profile and contained Beaker pottery and worked flint, including 10 small thumbnail scrapers. A large oval scoop or hollow abuts this ditch and contained small amounts of charcoal, Beaker pottery and worked flint, including a barbed and tanged arrowhead and five thumbnail scrapers. In Filed Z sherds from a small EBA Beaker decorated with rows of tooth-comb ornament were an isolated find from a small scoop.Middle Bronze Age: Five ditches on a north-south alignment excavated in Field T. Six ditches excavated in Field N, four of which appeared to form the sides of a possible enclosure measuring 150m by 180m. Ditches with steeply sloping sides and flat bases. Pottery included Deverell Rimbury ware. Two ditches terminated in Field Z and another merged with a further ditch and continued westwards. MBA pottery was also retrieved from four pits, one of which contained fingerprint impressed pottery and a large amount of burnt flint and hearthstone. A single cremation was excavated in Field Z consisting of poorly preserved bone within a plain vessel, this had been disturbed in antiquity.Late Bronze Age/Early Iron Age: short length of curving gully in Field T and 9 pit type features. A cluster of pits, all circular in shape and containing large quantities of raw and fired clay and burnt hearthstone. Two loom weights were also recovered. Two isolated pits containing LBA/EIA pottery were also found in Field T. In Field N three small pits were dated to this period.

Site_context_name: Flagstones Neolithic enclosure, Dorchester
Site_context_summary: A probable circular enclosure consisting of a single circuit of unevenly spaced pits constructed in the late 4th millennium cal. BC. There were two larger gaps in the circuit to the north and west. Four engravings were found on the sides of four segments and three primary burials (one cremation, the remainder inhumation) were placed in the base of segments, two beneath large stone slabs and the other close to another large stone. Another burial was cut into the primary fills of another segment.There is some suggestion for an earlier stone phase to this monument with a number of pits on the edge of the ditch segments and a large number of massive stones or deliberately broken fragments of stone in the fills of the segments.
Site_context_description: A probably circular enclosure partly revealed by excavation at Flagstones by Wessex Archaeology in 1987-1988 in advance of the construction of the Dorchester By-pass and further parts by geophysical survey in 1992. The excavated area included slightly over half of the enclosure circuit and a further small part of the northeastern side was revealed by geophysical survey. The full circuit has not been determined.The following description is abstracted from the final published report on the site (1). The numbers in square brackets refer to context numbers quoted in the report.The enclosure is about 100m in diameter and is defined by a single discontinuous circuit of ovoid pits [00399], some of them intercutting. The segments were unevenly spaced with many intercutting pits in the northwest and southwest parts of the excavated circuit and with causeways generally 0.5-2.5m wide between pits elsewhere. There were two wider gaps in the circuit to the north and to the west, perhaps denoting entrances. A total of 39 segments were exposed by the excavation and these were generally between 1.3-3m wide, 2-5.75m long and 0.75-1.4m deep with steep, almost vertical, sides and flat bottoms. The two pits (segments 35 & 36) each side of the wide gap in the north side of the circuit were very shallow with bowl-shaped profiles. The location of four further pits was found by geophysical survey in the area behind Max Gate House. Shallow engravings were found in four of the pits in the north, northwest, south and southwest parts of the circuit (segments 4, 12, 28, 34). These engravings comprised series of curvilinear lines, criss-cross patterns or more complex shapes (2). In common with many other features at Flagstones, there was a large amount of intrusive material found in this monument, largely a result of considerable root and animal disturbance.Primary burials were placed on the base of three segments. The cremated remains of an adult beneath a large sarsen slab were found in segment 16 in the west. Close by in segment 19 were the remains of a child inhumation beneath a large slab of calcareous sandstone. In the west terminal of segment 30 in the north was the crushed skeleton on a 6-12 month old child and the femur of a 3-5 year old. These were not under a slab but a large sarsen fragment was found nearby. Three radiocarbon dates were obtained from human bone and antler from the base of the pits gave a late 4th millenium BC date.Most of the segments appear to have filled rapidly and naturally with vacuous chalk rubble containing few finds. These included some earlier Neolithic bowl sherds, worked flint, 5 antler picks, a chalk ball, and a number of fragments of sarsen, limestone and sandstone with fresh breaks and some with signs of burning. The right femur of an adult was also recovered from the primary fill. Animal bone was mainly red deer with some cattle and dog bone. A pit was cut into the primary fills of segment 14 for the burial of a 10-12 year old child inhumation. A late 3rd millenium BC radiocarbon date was obtained from this skeleton. Above the primary fills was a stabilisation layer followed by weathering of the sides and further silting. A few finds were found in the stabilisation layer including 6 sherds of Neolithic bowl, one sherd of Late Iron Age/Roman pot, 19 pieces of worked flint, a small quantity of animal bone.  A grape pip was found in the stabilisation layer in segment 38. This produced a radiocarbon date of AD1640-1950. Finds from the silting layers above included Bronze Age flint (concentrated in the northwest part of the enclosure), 17 abraded sherds of Neolithic bowl, seven sherds of Late Iron Age pottery, four medieval sherds and small quantities of ceramic building material, fired clay, slag, and stone. 23 fragments of animal bone included cattle, horse,and red deer. The crouched inhumation of an adult male was found in segment 2 cut through the stabilisation layer. Fragments of human bone were also found in the silting layers of segment 28.The enclosure segments were finally filled with an upper layer of brown soil which was cut by Late Iron Age features. Finds were more productive from this layer than the earlier layers. They included a large quantity of Bronze Age flint, 42 sherds of Neolithic bowl, one Bronze Age sherd, 167 Late Iron Age sherds and 27 medieval and post-medieval sherds. Other finds included ceramic building material, shale waste, a fragment of copper alloy sheet and a coin of Constantine II. Fragments of human bone were also recovered and 127 fragments of animal bone, principally cattle.Mollusc data indicates a transition from grazed grassland at the time of construction to a combination of tillage and pasture within an increasingly open landscape.There is some suggestion of an earlier monument preceding the segmented enclosure. A number of small pits were found which had been cut by segments of the enclosure. These may represent stoneholes from an earlier monumental stone setting. There was a notable concentration of large stones and stone fragments in the enclosure segments which distinguishes this monument from other monuments nearby. And another large sarsen slab was found in the garden of Max Gate immediately to the west in 1891 (3). The stones may have been broken up or reused for burial when the segmented enclosure was constructed. The date of this postulated monument is not clear but stratigraphically, the indications are that it was not much earlier in date.

Site_context_name: A37 Western Link; Late Iron Age/ Early Roman Cemetery Structure 929
Site_context_summary: Evidence for a Late Iron Age/ Early Roman cemetery structure was discovered during excavations along the route of the Dorchester By-pass, Western Link.  Structure [929] was rectangular in plan and aligned NE-SW along the coombe side. The main structure measured 4.6m x 2m and was defined by a series of beam slots and surrounded by seven post-holes, four to the front and three to the rear, possibly supporting the roof and a veranda. A drainage gully was also excavated behind the structure. Pottery from the fills contained 2nd century and later Roman pottery. The structure was surrounded by at least 14 burials, which appear to have been deliberately set around it, mostly to the west. It is likely that this represents a funerary structure in use until at least the latter part of the 2nd century, at which time burials ceased.
Site_context_description: Found during a programme of archaeological work conducted by Wessex Archaeology along the route of the Dorchester By-pass, Western Link, Fordington Bottom, Dorchester between 1986 and 1988. The results of the excavations have been published as a Dorset Natural History and Archaeological Society Monograph; (DNHAS Monograph 11). The numbers in square brackets below refer to the context and feature numbers used in the published report (1).24 graves or possible graves are assigned to this period, from which the remains of 15 skeletons were recovered. All are considered to be of Late Iron Age/Early Roman date on the basis of associated grave goods and the form of burial. The graves are spread over a distance of c. 150m through trenches G/H and K along the coombe side. 14 graves were concentrated around structure [929] in Trench K, the remainder occurring as isolated graves. No contemporary settlement structures were identified in the area at this time. Two almost parallel narrow gullies [910] & [989] may have formed a cemetery boundary. These gullies could not be traced into Trench G/H but followed the alignment of the graves and enclosed an area around structure [929].Structure [929] was rectangular in plan and aligned NE-SW along the coombe side at the southern end of Trench K. The main structure measured 4.6m x 2m and was defined by a series of beam slots and surrounded by seven post-holes, four to the front and three to the rear, possibly supporting the roof and a veranda. A drainage gully was also excavated behind the structure. All the features were shallow (<0.2m deep) and had been disturbed by ploughing. Pottery from the beam slot fills suggests that the building was in use for a considerable time, it included 2nd century and later Roman pottery. The structure was surrounded by at least 14 burials, which appear to have been deliberately set around it, mostly to the west. The structure does not disturb any graves and no later graves encroach upon it. It is likely that this represents a funerary structure in use until at least the latter part of the 2nd century, at which time burials ceased in the area.

Site_context_name: A37 Western Link; Late Iron Age/ Early Roman Structure 420
Site_context_summary: Evidence for a Late Iron Age/ Early Roman structure was discovered during excavations along the route of the Dorchester By-pass, Western Link.  Structure [420] was located on the coombe side on the upper terrace at the southern end of Trench G, downslope and to the west of structure [394]. It was subrectangular, c. 4m long, 3.2m wide and 0.45m deep. The sunken floor was worn smooth. Several features cut it; two post holes, a gully [468] in which was the partial skeleton of a mature cow, a hearth and the terminal of a linear feature. A single infant burial [472] was also cut into the floor. Although the hearth suggests at least a partly domestic function, no occupation debris was recovered from the floor of the building and, after its abandonment, the remains of 35 sheep were dumped on the floor. The bones were in a condition, which suggested they had been quickly and deliberatley covered, sealed by a deposit of silty clay. The structure was subsequently covered by colluvium and then disturbed by a series of Early Roman gullies [418].

Site_context_name: Iron Age settlement on Southdown Ridge, Weymouth
Site_context_summary: An Iron Age settlement recorded during excavations in 2008-2009 in advance of construction of the Weymouth Relief Road. Road construction affected only the western edge of the settlement, which may have been very much larger.
Site_context_description: The settlement was established in the period c. 800-600 BC, the very earliest Iron Age, and appears not to have been enclosed at this time. It is not clear if the adjacent cross dyke was already in existence at this period, as dating evidence is inconclusive. The earliest activity on the site was the construction of at least one circular structure (7688); the excavators noted that there may have been other similar structures in adjacent unexcavated areas. This early settlement was greatly disturbed by later activity. The circular structure (7688) was situated at the south-western edge of the settlement, and consisted of a discontinuous curved gully marking part of a circular building around 13 metres in diameter. Postholes inside the gully suggested internal supports or partitions. Two large postholes formed a south-east facing entrance, and several postholes outside the entrance may have supported a porch. The filling of one of the postholes of the doorway contained earliest-early Iron Age pottery, as well as flecks of charcoal, slag and animal bone fragments. Quantities of heat-magnetised waste suggest that industrial activity may have been carried out in the vicinity. A fragment of shale armlet was also found, suggesting shale working on the site during this early phase of occupation. A well-preserved stretch of gully revealed evidence of construction methods   the base and sides of the gully were lined with slabs of limestone, which would have supported timber wall posts and/or planks. The positions of the doorway and porch postholes suggested that the doorway may have been realigned at some stage. Some of the postholes in this area were sealed by a layer of limestone pieces, forming a paved area. Several pieces of animal bone had been driven into the ground around the edge of this paved area, perhaps to secure stakes or a hide or textile cover. The paved area was covered by a rich deposit flecked with charcoal and containing fragments of pottery and animal bone, which spread beyond the paved area, and up to and into the top of the gully. The excavators felt that one possible explanation of this was that at the end of its life the building had been modified for use as an outdoor working area. Inside the building a shallow irregular hollow was filled with heat-magnetised material and a small oval stone-lined pit within the building contained a fragment of smithing hearth. A further indication of industrial use was the presence of shale waste in two of the postholes associated with this structure. A yard area next to this structure had quantities of occupation debris trampled into its surface, apparently re-deposited occupation or midden debris. including fuel ash slag, pottery, and fragments of an unfinished or failed casting of a copper alloy socketed axe, which may have been a deliberate deposition for votive purposes. The pottery included red-finished oolitic wares, furrowed bowls, jars with linear incised decoration and finger-impressed jars, of the late Bronze Age to early Iron Age transition. The decorated examples correspond stylistically to forms dated to the 8th-7th centuries BC at Kimmeridge. Animal bones in this layer represented various species, predominantly cattle but including sheep/goat, pig, and a dog. A flint shale working tool was also found in this layer, but may have been intrusive.Pits and postholes around the edges of the early Iron Age farm suggest that it may have been enclosed by an arrangement of fences that may have functioned in conjunction with the cross dyke. Unfortunately levelling of the site in the late Iron Age made it difficult to discern clearly the stratigraphic relationships between these various features. At an early stage, the southern side of the settlement was enclosed by a ditch and fence or palisade, possibly at the same time. Another fence line ran from the northern end of the cross dyke to a pit alignment on the northern side of the farm, which may have served as a boundary marker, as well as for storage. The excavators speculated that the fact that the fences were not replaced by an earthwork enclosure could suggest that settlement was not continuous and that there was a break in occupation of uncertain length, probably in the middle Iron Age.In the late Iron Age a terrace was cut into the scarp slope at the northern end of the settlement, cutting the ditch of an earlier penannular enclosure, and indicating that the enclosure must have been abandoned by this stage. The terrace was was around 8.5m wide and 0.60m high and reinforced by a stone revetment wall, but does not seem to have been the foundation of a building. It may have been erected to define a space, possibly for a small building or buildings which were subsequently robbed and/or truncated by later activity. In spite of this disturbance it was clear to the excavator s that this terraced area accommodated a complex of features including a double stone-lined drain, a single drain, and a paved path lined with low walls and a small alcove. The terrace was cobbled and re-surfaced or patched at least twice. Occupation material overlying the cobbles contained a few sherds of middle-late Iron Age pottery. The revetment wall was of dry-stone construction, surviving to a height of four courses, of roughly-shaped and unmodified limestone blocks and slabs. Some of the stones in the wall were burnt. Finds recovered from the yellowish-brown clayey silt filling between the stones included body sherds of a middle or late Iron Age burnished vessel in Poole Harbour ware, but also residual sherds more typical of early Iron Age date. A deposit formed largely of stone tumbled from the front of the wall contained pottery sherds dominated by Poole Harbour wares, including a late Iron Age necked jar and cordoned ovoid jar. The terraced area appeared to have been re-organised while in use and was disturbed and truncated by later activity. This made it difficult to interpret the date, function and character of the complex, not least whether it accommodated a structure of any sort. However, the excavators felt that the terrace might have been created as a level, drained space in which various domestic or craft activities might be carried out, probably during the late Iron Age. A concentration of shale working waste, including offcuts and bracelet/armlet fragments, was found in a soil layer overlying the stony spread, and suggesting that a shale workshop was situated somewhere in the complex. In the very late Iron Age, probably during the 1st century AD, the nucleus of the settlement was levelled using stone robbed from earlier buildings and midden-like material brought from elsewhere, possible from part of the settlement outside the excavated area.  This midden like deposit (7002) was thick, varied but highly organic, and sealed several late Iron Age burials. The purpose of the levelling was unclear but seemed to mark the return of the area to agricultural use.

Site_context_name: FORE DOWN - Bronze Age cairn cemetery, Bronze Age barrow
Site_context_summary: Possible site of a barrow group, excavated by Croft Andrew c1942.
Site_context_description: On the steep, south facing slope of Fore Down, there formerly existed a group of  barrows or cairns. The approximate location of the group is indicated on a map of Dudley, but she did not know their exact number or locations. She states that CK Croft Andrew excavated here, that Patchett saw the pots, and that the downland they were in was enclosed during WWII (b1). Patchett, who had information from Croft Andrew, describes the urn discovered here as markedly biconical, with large handles and with a carination at handle level. The pot had a slight cordon at the neck, and an everted rim with very slanting internal bevel. The impressed cord ornament consisted of four horizontal lines and a band of chevrons. A dagger was associated (b2). In 1973, the OS fieldworker could provide no further insights into these barrows either through fieldwork or documentary research (h2). The finds are listed by Pearce (b3) and illustrated by Christie who records that the finds, a handled urn, a dagger and a flint, were rescued by Croft Andrew from the mutilated barrow during his Davidstow Moor campaign, and which are now in Truro Museum (b4, 5, 6).--------------------------------Site history:2: 1973. MHB/OS--------------------------------

Site_context_name: BUSVARGUS - Bronze Age barrow, Bronze Age lithic scatter
Site_context_summary: A barrow is recorded on Busvargus Hill in which an urn was found c1900; the are no remains.
Site_context_description: Henderson, probably quoting Thomas (b1), records "in a croft close to the road" on Busvargus Hill between Tregeseal and Leswidden clay works, are the remains of a ring barrow (cairn with peristalith) 66 feet in diameter. 500 yards south in the corner of a field next the road once stood an ancient barrow. Slight traces of a mound and one large stone remain. An urn was found c1900 in excellent preservation, bearing chevron ornament. In the field to the east of the barrow many flint flakes are annually ploughed up, including a few worked flints" (b2). Russell records extant remains of a barrow (b3). A site visit by the OS in 1960 failed to locate the barrows, but it is suggested that one may be at SW 381 314 while the second could have been at SW 381 310. The present wherabouts of the urn are not known (h1). Subsequent fieldwork revealed no trace of the sites (h2).--------------------------------Site history:1: 1960. GEARY, E / OS2: 1975. Site_context_name: TRETHELLAN FARM - Bronze Age burial, Bronze Age round house (domestic)
Site_context_summary: One of seven MBA roundhouses set along a broad south-west facing terrace at Trethellan Farm.
Site_context_description: Trethellan Bronze Age village comprised at least seven roundhouses which were set in a row along a broad south-west facing terrace. House 2222 was sealed beneath several layers of soil which produced large quantities of pottery. Discovered late in the excavation,  the history of occupation appeared to have been relatively straightforward, and the house was excavated rapidly. The house was set in a circular hollow, c11m in diameter; it consisted of a single ring of closely-set post holes and traces of a stone wall revetting the hollow. A total of 228 stake holes were recorded in the interior. Several phases of activity were identified, each differing only slightly, and not representing any major change in patterns of use or construction. A well sealed deposit from the central hearth gave a Carbon-14 date centred on 3091 BP (uncalibrated) (2).The incomplete remains of an extended adult male inhumation were discovered in a rectangular pit, 1.8m long, aligned north-east/south-west, in the build-up of the layers in the central hearth.  The hearth was clearly re-used after this interment. Site_context_name: HIGHER BUSSOW - Bronze Age hut circle settlement, Bronze Age field system, Bronze Age findspot, Iron Age hut circle settlement, Iron Age findspot

Site_context_description: Two hut circles are recorded on current OS maps. These were once part of a larger group: Henderson recorded that a large number of huts and other remains were destroyed when clearing fields (sometime prior to 1912). Site_context_name: CHYSAUSTER - Bronze Age cairn, Bronze Age cup marked stone
Site_context_summary: An excavated cairn initially interpreted as a hut circle. The cairn was the focus for a number of cremations, six of which were associated with urns of Middle Bronze Age date.
Site_context_description: A cairn on the slopes above Chysauster was initially interpreted as a hut circle in the 1950s during a survey by the OS. A subsequent OS visit in 1975 cast doubt on this interpretation; the surveyor then suggesting that it was in fact a clearance cairn. Excavation and survey by CAU and the CEU in 1984 proved it to be a Bronze Age funerary cairn. The monument is sited within a later IA/RB field system (36007.7). Excavations revealed a kerbed cairn, over 6m in diameter, comprising large granite blocks, each with one natural approximately flat surface and most of similar height, placed in position so that the flat faces made up the outer perimeter of a quite accurate circle; an apparent entrance c2m wide was incorporated on its south side. The body of the cairn was made up of sub-angular granite blocks laid mainly horizontally to produce a flattened top, level with the tops of the kerb stones. The exposed surface of one of the top stones of the infill, close to the possible entrance gap had a pecked cup-mark. The cairn was the focus for a number of cremations (9), six of which were associated with urns. The cairn had several structural phases. Within the main central body two adjacent features contained urned cremation burials and appear to have been the primary burials around which the cairn was designed. Placed outside the cairn kerb were a further six irregularly spaced satellite burials, four of which contained complete pots. Two further pits, shallow and truncated by ploughing, were located north-east of the cairn kerb with one containing a fragment of pottery.Finds included Trevisker style cremation urns, worked flint debitage, an amber bead, an ovoid slate disc, quartz crystals and a worked pebble (b7). A buried soil sampled from beneath the kerbed stones, provided a calibrated radiocarbon date 2280-1780BC. Radiocarbon dates from the cremation urns showed the monument to have been in use during the  Middle Bronze Age with the period c1800-1500 cal BC proposed as the bracket in which it was at one time built and used (b7). The site was reinstated after excavation and now sits in an area of enclosed croft (h4).Charcoal (Quercus sp.) was extracted from the top of the old land surface beneath cairn 38, context OLS 534 (7). The charcoal occurred over a fairly wide area and was scattered; ie it was not just a result of a small fire but may be the result of clearance of the woodland prior to the construction of the cairn. Radiocarbon dating from an oak sample from this deposit returned a date of 3650 80 BP (HAR-6548) - current calibration provides a date of 2_: 2280-1770 cal BC (b9).--------------------------------Site history:1: 1960. GEARY, E / OS2: 1975. FLETCHER, MJ / OS4: 1985. NOWAKOWSKI, J AND SHARPE, A / CAU--------------------------------

Site_context_name: TRYE - Bronze Age cairn, Bronze Age standing stone

Excavation showed that the menhir stood by a cairn of stones, below which was a cremation and a beaker vessel contained within a cist (31514.01). At the base, the sides are 0.6m wide and the stone is 2.5m high. There are no surface remains of the cairn (h2). Site_context_name: DULOE - Bronze Age cairn, Bronze Age stone circle
Site_context_summary: Duloe, the smallest stone circle in Cornwall comprising eight quartz stones, possibly the remains of an elaborate cairn.
Site_context_description: Duloe stone circle is the smallest in Cornwall and is shown on the 1st Edition OS 2500 map of c1880, described as a 'Druidical Circle'. It is slightly oval in plan and measures 11.7m by 10.2m. The circle comprises eight stones, seven of which are still standing; the northernmost stone has fallen and lies broken. All the stones are quartz and vary in height between 1.0m and 2.4m. The stone circle was reconstructed in the mid 1800s (7)WC Borlase relates two conflicting stories about the urn which was found at this site. In an account of the attempt in 1861 to re-erect three (?) fallen stones, credited to one Mr Pedlar, the urn was recovered from beneath one of the stones. A fragment of this urn is illustrated by Borlase. However, Mr NHP Lawrence of Launceston subsequently stated in a letter (to TH Bewes and seen by Borlase) that the urn was recovered from a hedge that bisected the circle when this was removed, either before 1858 or between 1861-63. Human bone was found inside the urn. Borlase inferred from these details that a burial monument or cairn had been raised inside the circle.Patchett (1946) lists the urn as Class 'G' Deverel-Rimbury style which she ascribes to the Late Bronze Age and dates to "after 750 BC".The circle is in excellent condition but recent plans to make the farm into a tourist attraction might disturb the nature of the site.The stone circle was plotted from aerial photographs (p1) during the Cornwall NMP.--------------------------------Site history:1: 1971.
