Site_context_name: HARLYN BAY - Bronze Age round house (domestic), Iron Age cemetery
Site_context_summary: An Iron Age cemetery with over 100 graves, part of a walled structure and lots of artefacts were revealed by excavations at Harlyn Bay in 1900 and 1976
Site_context_description: During site works in advance of the construction of a house at Harlyn Bay in 1900, the remains of an Iron Age cemetery were revealed. An excavation was undertaken by Mr Reddie Mallett (apparently the owner of the site) (b1), and about 110 graves were discovered. Part of a curved wall was also found,  with two burials found beneath its foundation, which were interpreted as 'votive offerings' (b9). The other burials were in graves  aligned N-S, with the head at the north, and the bodies were crouched or contracted (b1,9). The interments (not cremations) were accompanied by a range of bronze, iron and ceramic grave goods (b5,9). The 'excavation archive' now held by the Royal Cornwall Museum, in Truro (b8), consists of the excavator's notes and a guidebook written by Mr Buller in 1912 (b3), which is extremely confused. Finds from the excavation of the cemetery at Harlyn Bay in 1900 are listed separately in records detailing metalwork, pottery, stone, bone and shell because of the difficulty of associating individual finds with particular graves or excavated contexts 21700.3-.6). It appears from the original excavation archive notes that only a few of the burials had grave goods, and of those found it is not clear what proportion eventually found their way to Truro Museum.  In 1976, the site was re-examined by Rowan Whimster when the  building that had been used as a museum was to be extended into a bungalow (b9). Although only a small area was excavated, the written and artefactual archives were re-examined and it was possible to clarify the interpretation of the site. However, the site archive contained details of only 40 of  the burials - the other 70 remain unlocated. The main feature revealed by Whimster was a length of drystone walling set on a clay-bonded foundation course dug into the old ground surface (b9). This was considered to be part of the same feature as that seen in 1900, which was interpreted as part of a  'ritual structure',  a conclusion accepted by Whimster.  This feature was deliberately demolished not long after construction. No new burials were found, and only one pit  from the 1900 excavations was encountered.  Because the acid soils of Cornwall destroy all traces of bone, this site, inundated by dune sand, is one of the few with surviving human skeletal material making it  one of  the most important prehistoric sites in the county.Charcoal samples from the floor of the circular building and from an old land surface prior to the inundation of the site by dune sand both gave dates in the Middle Bronze Age. The circular structure (house?) was dated to 3320-3600 BP (1820-2100 BC) and the OLS to 3460-3640 BP (1960-2140 BC).  The circular structure therefore appears to be a middle Bronze Age round house rather than an Iron age 'ritual structure'.  This highlights doubts about the accuracy of the 1900 excavation archive and also about whether Whimster's wall and the 1900 wall are in fact parts of the same structure. It also recalls Nowakowskis' discovery at Trethellan Farm,Newquay, of  Iron Age burials over the remains of a  Bronze Age village (PRN 171472).--------------------------------Site history:2: 1954. ALFR/ OS3: 1970. MJF/ OS5: 1985. SHEPPARD PA/DOE--------------------------------<MCO704>: A number of stone objects were found with the burials in the 1900 excavation at Harlyn Bay. Parts of two thin shale bracelets were found, presumably imported from southern Britain. Four small tools had been made from the rather soft local slate, including a  20cm long knife, two needles and a borer. These could not have been used to work any hard material but may have been used for net-making for example.  Other slate pieces were found that could also have possibly been utilised.  These objects are very unusual and without close parallel in Cornwall.Seven spindle whorls, made from pottery, stone, slate and bone were found. It has been assumed that they came singly from female graves, though there is no evidence for this. Spindle whorls are rarely found in Iron Age graves,There were also a number of sharpened bits of shell, possibly used for sewing or for dealing with shellfish. Three lumps of ochre were found. There were a number of pebbles possibly used for sling stones, and there were six bits of flint of unknown date, presumably residual. Animal bones were found in and around the cists, including ox, sheep, horse and pig.  Hencken says that mice bones found in a child's grave may have been intrusive rather than ritual objects.--------------------------------Site history:2: 1954. ALFR/ OS3: 1970. MJF/ OS5: 1979. SHEPPARD PA/ DOE6: 1985. SHEPPARD PA/ DOE--------------------------------<MCO705>: A number of potsherds were found in the excavation of the Iron Age cemetery at Harlyn Bay in 1900. Whimster suggests that  few were associated with the burials, but instead came from a cooking midden at the southern edge of the site. Most of the pottery was well fired Iron Age or Romano-British wares, including a few sherds of South-West decorated ware 'similar to that found at Glastonbury'. One sherd was found close to the mouth of one of the interments and may have been used as an amulet (b9).--------------------------------Site history:2: 1954. ALFR/ OS3: 1970. MJF/ OS5: 1979. SHEPPARD PA/ DOE6: 1985. SHEPPARD PA/ DOE--------------------------------<MCO19614>: Curving sections of stone wall revealed by excavations at Harlyn Bay in 1900  were interpreted as part of a round house or circular ritual structure. The drystone wall was set on  heavy clay-bonded  foundation slabs. The foundation was set in a trench cut into the old ground surface, and the wall was revetted with soil layers.  It was reported that the bones of  two individuals were found crushed under one of the foundation slabs. Bullen (b3) thought that the wall was part of the cemetery's perimeter wall, but the more popular explanation was that this was  part of a hut or ritual structure, and that the burials were some kind of votive offering.  In 1976, the site was re-examined by Rowan Whimster when the  building, which had been used as a museum, was due to be extended into a bungalow (b9). Although only a small area was excavated, the written and artefactual archives were re-examined at the same time and it was possible to clarify the interpretation of the site. The main feature revealed by Whimster was a length of walling which was considered to be part of the same feature as that seen in 1900, which was interpreted as a  'ritual structure',  a conclusion accepted by Whimster.  This feature was deliberately demolished not long after construction. No new burials were found, and only one pit  from the 1900 excavations was encountered.  The structure produced a range of artefacts including two sherds of black fabric, "possibly from an earlier phase of occupation of the site", a couple of flints, probably residual, and fragments of bone of horse, pig, ox and duck (b9). This reflects the range of bones found in the rest of the cemetery (b1). The two bodies buried under the wall of the structure were found to have three fragments of an iron bracelet and a bronze ring. Sadly there seems to be no  illustrations of these finds and their present location is unknown. Charcoal samples from the floor of the circular building and from an old land surface prior to the inundation of the site by dune sand both gave dates in the Middle Bronze Age. The circular structure (house?) was dated to 3320-3600 BP (1820-2100 BC) and the OLS to 3460-3640 BP (1960-2140 BC).  The circular structure therefore appears to be a middle Bronze Age round house rather than an Iron age 'ritual structure'.  This highlights doubts about the accuracy of the 1900 excavation archive and also about whether Whimster's wall and the 1900 wall are in fact parts of the same structure. It also seems unlikely that the two skeletons could actually have come from beneath the wall of the structure.--------------------------------Site history:2: 1954. ALFR/ OS3: 1970. MJF/ OS5: 1979. SHEPPARD PA/ DOE6: 1985. SHEPPARD PA/ DOE--------------------------------In 1900, about 130 graves were excavated in the Iron Age cemetery at Harlyn Bay. Records  exist for less than 50 of them, consisting usually of only a rough location plan and a small sketch (b1). Most of the graves were aligned N-S, apparently in rows,  although some were cut into earlier burials. The graves were all stone lined, and mainly rectangular; heads were generally at the north  end. The grave cuts were  just large enough for a crouched or contracted adult and smaller graves were interpreted as children's. The alignment of the heads to the north is indicative of Iron Age interments.  A few burials were in oval or irregular graves, and some were in double graves. One 'family' burial had been disturbed by a later  addition.The skeletons were not well recorded, but included men and women, family grouos and seven children (unusual in such cemeteries). Although pathological features were not recorded, some  information on burial customs was recovered. Bullen describes one area as  being full of mixed bones, possibly a charnel house for bone fragments found during later interments. There was a group of disturbed burials in cists to the south of the others. Two cists contained collections of skulls,  one with five, the other with three in a line facing west. One skull lay at the foot of its skeleton, and one burial had sword cuts to the skull.--------------------------------Site history:2: 1954. ALFR/ OS3: 1970. MJF/ OS5: 1979. SHEPPARD PA/ DOE6: 1985. SHEPPARD PA/ DOE--------------------------------<MCO25845>: The excavation of the harlyn bay cemetary by mallett et al in 1900 uncovered  evidence of a midden to the s. It remains uncertain what finds were removed from this midden, and whimster has suggested that the pottery allegedely  found in the graves may in fact have come from this midden. Bullen's report suggests that slate and shell implements, and spindle whorls of various materials were found in the midden, but these were described by whimster as being from the burials. It is not certain whether the midden is connected with the cemetary at all, and it may represent the periphery of a settlement  site of any iron age date. See (21700) for more general details of the  cemetery.

Site_context_name: TREGIFFIAN - Neolithic, Early Bronze Age entrance grave
Site_context_summary: Remains of a barrow with an entrance passage, found during excavation to incorporate cup marked stones and to contain cremated bone and an undamaged urn.
Site_context_description: Tregiffian barrow is situated approx 100m to the SE of Goon Rith Menhir (28191) and 260m SW of the Merry Maidens stone circle (28200).  It was first recorded by WC Borlase in 1863 (b1) and was 'opened' by him in 1868. Having removed the turf from the mound he observed that "it became quite evident that that....stones had been taken from it to make the surrounding hedges and their place supplied by a pile of mud and refuse from the road" so it is difficult to be certain about the original form and ground plan of the monument.  He recorded a ring of perimeter stones and a large inclined capstone 2.7m in diameter and 0.45m thick resting on two uprights at the south and west sides and on the ground on the other side, having apparently been knocked of its supports by what he (probably mistakenly) identified as a menhir. He recorded a great quantity of ashes and bone splinters and a flint flake, but no pottery or metalwork (b2). Henderson gave the position of the barrow, which he said is still visible, as adjoining the hedge and some 90m west of the stile leading to the Merry Maidens field, and noted that the menhir referred to by Borlase had disappeared (b3). The OS surveyed the barrow at 1:2500 in 1960 and recorded the remains of the SE half of a mound which resembled a barrow. This had a maximum height of 2.0m and a diameter of approx 17m which had been augmented by the dumping of field clearance material on the NE and SW. They also recorded that the barrow was cut across by a NE- SW hedge and that there were no traces of a mound on the road verge to the NW of the hedge (h1). Tregiffian barrow was excavated by Dorothy Dudley for the MPBW in 1967 and 1968; she recorded that the barrow may have originally been 12m in diameter. A megalithic passage 4.3m long and 1.2m wide was discovered, surrounded by a setting of large granite slabs 0.9m to 1.2m high, at about 0.9m from the outer edge of this passage. The stones blocking the entrance, one of them cup marked, had been displaced by Borlase. Slightly east of the entrance a 1.1m square granite block, covered with a whole group of cup marks had been set at an angle to the entrance (28192.2). Another large cup marked stone was found lying in the SE quadrant. The floor of the passage was strewn with comminuted bone fragments and below this floor were two pits. An oval one contained charcoal, stone and cremated bone, and a round one held an undamaged urn 38cm high (h2, h3, b4, b5). A further excavation  was carried out by A Apsimon for the DOE, in 1972, to supplement Dudley's work in 1967/68. This  was confined to the completion of the plan of the chamber prior to conservation and restoration (h4, b7). Russell in 1971 listed the site and recorded the extant remains of a barrow with a stone structure (b6). Sheppard in 1982 noted that the ground on each side of the outer ring of stones had been eroded by visitors. The bare strips were approx 3.6m long by 0.6m wide (b8). The entrance grave is visible on aerial photographs. The monument was included in the Schedule on 9/12/1968 and the scheduling revised on 20/2/1996.--------------------------------Site history:1: 1960. QUINNELL, NV /OS--------------------------------

Site_context_name: CONSTANTINE ISLAND - Iron Age hut circle
Site_context_summary: Two Iron Age hut circles on Constantine Island.
Site_context_description: Constantine Island is a small peninsula 35m by 15m in size divided from the land at high tide and now suffering much erosion. The top is said to be a raised beach but this may be an illusion as the sand that spreads over the whole area has also been deposited here. In the early C20 the remains of two huts and a cremation with grave goods, were found. There are now negligible remains apart from an underlying layer of flints (21721), probably a scatter from the many well-preserved midden deposits (21730.6 and 21731). The huts and cremation were dated to the La Tene Iron Age, and probably form part of the settlement found close to the island on the mainland (21731). Crawford found a stone axe in 1921 (b4).--------------------------------Site history:1: 1901. PENROSE WILLIAMS/ WHE2: 1904. ARTHUR, JP / PRIVATE3: 1920. CRAWFORD, OGS / OS4: 1970. MJF / OS--------------------------------<MCO25847>: Penrose Williams has described a cist found on Constantine Island, the exact location of the cist is uncertain; the bones were found in a poorly cremated state and fractured by dampness. JP Arthur claims the bones were "arranged in a neat little heap between two small slabs of slate" (b1) but also has suggested a story about cannibalism following Williams observation that the bones seemed to have been cut up after death; a later specialist report clearly showed the error of this idea but continued by claiming that the body was female, of 5ft 5in height. Claims of this sort  are impossible to substantiate from bones in such poor condition. Some sherds of a black hand made pot were found in the cist, with some flint flakes and a worked piece of quartzite. The site could not be definitely located, but may have lain within one of two hollows on the island that may be the result of excavations (b10).--------------------------------Site history:1: 1901. PENROSE WILLIAMS / WWE2: 1904. ARTHUR, JP / PRIVATE3: 1920. CRAWFORD, OGS / DOE4: 1970. MJF / OS5: 1978. NDJ /CCRA--------------------------------<MCO46104>: At the northern edge of Constantine Island a pair of upright slate slabs can be seen protruding from wind blown sand deposits at a depth of approximately 2.0m below the surface. Above and to the southwest a larger flat laid slate slab  rests  upon the upright stones. The arrangement of stones and their position within aeolian deposits suggests a built structure and the most likely interpretation is that these stones represent a cist burial. This is likely to date to the Early Bronze Age. The cist, although visible in the cliff edge, is not at any immediate risk from erosion since it lies on the leeward side of the island. The ground around it is covered with thick grassy vegetation and this is preventing erosion on the scale apparent elsewhere on the island (b1).<MCO46105>: A polished granite implement was recovered during a field survey from an eroding cliff face on the northwestern side of Constantine Island (b1). The tool had been broken in antiquity and the sub-oval fragment recovered measured 11cm by 4cm along its longest face and tapered to a width of 2cm. It has been identified as a lapstone (Carl Thorpe pers comm) used for polishing leather. It is likely to be of prehistoric origin. The stone came from a pocket of the midden material covering the island at a depth of 0.4m below the surface. Numerous fragments of burnt bone were also recovered from the vicinity of the lapstone within the same deposit. The stratigraphy here seemed disturbed in comparison with the well-stratified midden material to either side, perhaps indicating an intrusion into the midden. This might indicate a cist burial eroding out of the cliff, and thus a Bronze Age date, although no structural features were observed. The artefact has been returned to the NT warden for the Holywell Bay - Camel Estuary area.<MCO25848>: In 1902 Penrose Williams reported the discoverey of a cist on Constantine Island (PRN21730.3). A deposit of similar bones were found nearby, in the same condition. He suggested that they were of a similar origin, but had been discarded by the finder as being of no interest. No more details; a similar La Tene date as the other cist is assumed.--------------------------------Site history:1: 1901. PENROSE WILLIAMS / WWE2: 1904. ARTHUR, JP / PRIVATE3: 1920. Site_context_name: HIGHGATE - Bronze Age enclosure
Site_context_summary: Highgate ritual enclosure, an Early Bronze Age cremation site discovered during a watching brief in advance of the Indian Queens bypass.
Site_context_description: Highgate ritual enclosure is an Early Bronze Age site of a previously undocumented type. It was discovered during a watching brief undertaken during the initial stages of the construction of the A30 Indian Queens bypass. The site comprised an oval space, 10m by 12m, defined by a series of shallow segmented ditches and postholes forming a horse-shoe arrangement. Towards the centre lay a fairly deep pit containing a cremation in a decorated urn. The urn had been broken either before or during the act of depostion and the pit had been sealed with a black silty layer. Close by was a large quartz block embedded in the clay subsoil - possibly a marker stone. The cremation was found to include a bronze awl among the bone fragments.  There was no sign of a mound over this feature. The site lies only 50m to the north of Little Gaverigan barrow (171736).

Site_context_name: TRESVENNACK PILLAR - Bronze Age standing stone
Site_context_summary: Tresvennack Pillar is a perfectly upright, well squared and symmetrical stone, 4.0m high, with an ancient vertical split going right through.
Site_context_description: WC Borlase describes Tresvennack Pillar as a perfectly upright, well squared and symmetrical stone, 3.5m in height above ground and about 1.2m below ground. At the front of the stone two urns were discovered in 1840 (28707.1) (b1). The menhir is marked on the OS map of 1906 (b3) and was scheduled in 1950 (b5). SHEPPARD, PA / DOE--------------------------------<MCO1652>: Edmunds in 1848 records the find of two urns at the foot of Tresvennack Pillar (28707) in 1840 by JNR Millett. Site_context_name: CONSTANTINE BAY - Iron Age hut circle settlement
Site_context_summary: Remains of and Iron Age settlement, excavated in he early C20.
Site_context_description: The remains found on the mainland opposite Constantine Is land are just as confusing as those on the island. The records kept of excavations and finds were not adequate, and it remains uncertain whether one or two huts were found, as the locations of finds remains unclear. In fact it seems that Arthur's reports (b2) led to most of the confusion as he may have mixed  features on the island with those on the mainland. His unreliability has been noted in regard to the island remains (921730) and the aspects in which he has caused confusion will be detailed on the sub records below. It is clear that the site lies on and in an extensive midden deposit, in which both bones and shells and an urn and a piece of bronze were found in the layers. A hut was built on the midden layers and was subsequently partly covered by further layers of midden material; it was well excavated and beautifully drawn by Penrose Williams. It was quite obviously round, but there are reports by Arthur of at least one, and possibly two, other huts, one of which was pear-shaped (like the hut on Constantine Island). The other had only one wall, one having fallen away with the cliff (like a feature on the island). He describes the latter as containing a hearth, however, unlike the island one. He also mentions a small cist enclosing grass seeds, some of which were apparently grown. This is a highly improbable result from Iron Age grass seeds kept in a damp environment. It seems likely that Arthur's comments were made from second or third hand reports, and it is hard to know what value to place on his comments. The problems were exacerbated when a field study in 2003 identified new locations for sites in addition to the sites already mapped from antiquitarian sources (b9).(b7) - Johnson, ND, 1980, Pers Comm to SMR--------------------------------Site history:2: 1970. HAT / OS3: 1980. NDJ / CCRA--------------------------------<MCO19366>: This site was variously described as  slate mine  and  slate hut or cist  on excavation maps from the 1920s (b7). The site consisted of disordered slate slabs laid on top of raised beach deposits (b5). No remains were observed at this location and it is possible that the site has been destroyed. If the site was a cist, a stone-lined box used for burial, then these features are usually of Early Bronze Age date (2000-1700 BC). However Iron Age or early medieval cists are also found (b8).--------------------------------Site history:: 1980. JOHNSON, ND / CCRA1: 1913. PENROSE WILLIAMS2: 1970. HAT / OS4: 1970. FLETCHER, MJ5: 1978. JOHNSON, ND / CCRA--------------------------------<MCO25852>: A hut on the mainland opposite Constantine Island was excavated by Penrose Williams c1912 (b4). Williams' notes suggest that the location of the hut was on the edge of an eroding cliff face. The hut was 6.5m across and completely circular with a small entrance with internal slabs and porch at the south-east, with the  walls built of slate blocks up to about 60cm high. Internally two slabs lay near the door and there was a central hearth with what appears to be a  square oven made from slate slabs and filled with reddened clay. There seem to have been no postholes and presumably the roof timbers rested on top of  the wall. The finds from the hut are listed by Williams and many are well illustrated. The finds included a piece of Glastonbury ware and other rough pottery, a piece of worked bone, some spindle whorls, a slate dagger, a human mandible, some pestles, large slates with holes, polished pebbles,  burned stones and clay, two pieces of cuttlefish, and bones of ox, sheep and  pig. There was no mention of shells even though the site is close to the sea  and is surrounded by and was overlain by a shell midden (21731.1). In addition to the domestic animal bones, rabbit bones were found outside the hut. Penrose Williams records an urn which is probably that referred to by Hencken (b6) as coming from the midden. A field survey in 2003 revealed a length of curved stone kerbing, visible in a section of eroding cliff top. The kerbing consists of two parallel arcs of flat-laid slate blocks 1.5m wide and packed with rubble. Only the top of a single course is visible. Another area of jumbled slates lies 8-9m to the east and may represent the opposite side of a roundhouse (b8). This site is likely to be one of the sites excavated or recorded in the early C20.--------------------------------Site history:1: 1913. PENROSE WILLIAMS2: 1970. HAT / OS3: 1970. FLETCHER, MJ / OS4: 1978. JOHNSON, ND / CCRA5: 1980. JOHNSON, ND / CCRA6: 1989. JOHNSON, ND / CAU--------------------------------<MCO25853>: Following examination of the wall remaining from a hut on the mainland opposite Constantine Island (21731.4), a deposit of grass seeds was found enclosed in slate slabs. They were identified as triticum perenne and were in good order. Crawford says that the seeds were grown, but this seems improbable for Iron Age seed. It remains wholly uncertain whether the seeds were Iron Age in origin but were well preserved by the calcareous sand and  lack of light, or whether they were some sort of late introduction to an  earlier cist, implying a possible iron age burial. The feature is no longer extant.--------------------------------Site history:1: 1913. PENROSE WILLIAMS2: 1970. HAT / OS3: 1970. FLETCHER, MJ4: 1978. JOHNSON, ND / CCRA5: 1980. Site_context_name: HALANGY PORTH - Neolithic occupation site, Bronze Age occupation site
Site_context_summary: An area of Neolithic/Bronze Age occupation near the cliff edge; no remains are now visible.
Site_context_description: Gray found an area of Neolithic/Bronze Age occupation near the cliff edge, where he dug four pits ('H-K' on Gray's distribution map). Pit 'H', at SV 9092 1252, (re-lettered 'A' by the OS), revealed an occupation floor of black earth with sherds, unfired clay, part fired sherds, bones, a scraper and charcoal. It lay 0.9m below the surface, was 10cm deep and was separated by 14cm of blown sand from an earlier layer containing sherds, flint cores and flakes, clay and charcoal. Pit 'I', at SV 9092 1253 (re-lettered 'B' by the OS), collapsed inward before it was completely excavated. It included a layer of stones, embedded evenly in sticky black soil or clay, together with much pottery (mostly fragments of large jars), midden materials and flints. Pit 'J', at SV 9093 1254 (re-lettered 'D' by the OS), exposed a burnt ram floor beneath 0.5m of sterile soil and 15cm of black earth containing stones and rough pottery. Sunk into the ram (periglacial head) was the lower part of a large storage jar, 32cm diameter at the base and 41cm diameter with a height of 25cm. It was weathered at the top indicating long previous exposure, and contained silt, pottery, a few pieces of charcoal and calcined bone. This pot is now reconstructed and preserved in Penzance museum. About 10cm south at a slightly higher level was the base of another pot, not in situ, similar to one from 'H'. Another 'floor' lay about 30cm east, being burnt to a depth of 3cm-6cm to a bright red colour, possibly having been used for pottery firing. Pit 'K', at SV 9093 1254 (re-lettered 'C' by the OS) consisted of a wall varying in height  from one course to 0.6m, with pottery fragments, mainly from large jars, being plentiful along its sides. There was much worked flint and some charcoal possibly indicating a hearth. The structure was not considered a dwelling but possibly a form of revetment which appeared to have been levelled after desertion; the stone was probably used at the adjacent Romano-British site (7442). No remains were visible at this location in 1988 (h2).--------------------------------Site history:2: 1988. RATCLIFFE, J / CAU--------------------------------

Site_context_name: MCO1906: CATACLEWS POINT - Bronze Age barrow cemetery
Site_context_summary: A line of six barrows were situated on the cliff edge at Cataclews Point, only four of which still survive.
Site_context_description: A line of six barrows were situated on the cliff edge at Cataclews Point; they would have been a prominent skyline feature from Harlyn Bay and very visible from the sea. The barrows are numbered sequentially (.1 to .6) from east to west. Five of the barrows (nos 2-6) are plotted on the OS 1st Ed 2500 map, but only four are still extant. The easternmost , no 1, was built over by the Admiralty during WW2, and the westernmost , no 6, was removed in 1944 in advance of an extension to quarrying, or to prevent it from slipping into the adjacent quarry (h3). The remaining four all seem to have been investigated at one time or another, but the records of these activities are far from clear. Because of the difficulty of associating a particular account with a specific barrow the excavations are described below. It is likewise difficult to associate specific finds with specific barrows and again, these are described below.Penrose Williams excavated at least one of the barrows in about 1912 with C Mott (b2). It is uncertain which one it was but from his sketches, and his description "the one nearest to Cataclews Quarry", it would appear that barrow 1 or 2 was the one involved. An urn was found inverted over a cremation in a small cist covered by a cairn of large stones 9.0m across and 1.6m high (b2). The mouth of the vessel seems to be that illustrated in Patchett as D8 (b6).An excavation was carried out by OGS Crawford for the Zoological Society in or before 1921 (b3). It is suggested that this involved barrow no 4. A collared urn was found in this excavation and it has been suggested that it was accompanied by a stone axe-hammer or batle-axe and a small urn or food vessel (h6). The urn, which does not seem to have been illustrated, was light yellow in colour with thin smooth sides. The axe was described as 'quartzose conglomerate'. All these finds are said to be in Truro Museum.It is reported that another excavation was carried out by a Mr Pocock at an unknown date on one of the barrows. It is possible this was the same event as the excavation by the Zoological Society above. However, a local man, Mr Hellyar from Harlyn House, suggested that it was barrow no 5 that was examined by Mr Pocock.It is also suggested that Mr Hellyar himself excavated one of the barrows before 1912. Penrose Williams included a sketch of one the vessels found in this excavation in his report on his own 1912 excavation, but there is no reason to assume that it came from the same site, as Hencken suggested. An illustration of this urn is in the Information File, and is Patchett's E12 (b6).There is also evidence for 'excavations' here before those described above. An urn was found in one of the barrows on Cataclews Point in or before 1731 (b10, but original source unknown), and some bones were found under the stones in one of the barrows before 1890 (according to W Iago in JRIC Vol 10, 185-262). It is not known in either case which barrow was opened. Three of the barrows (.2, .3 and .5) are included in the Schedule.(b7) - Hellyar, L, 1954, Pers Comm to OS, , --------------------------------Site history:5: 1954. Site_context_description: On the summit and slopes of Chapel Carn Brea lies a group of ten barrows. Of these, six are prominent certain prehistoric structures while the other four are mounds traced during fieldwork (h3) which appear to represent barrows. During the Bronze Age a round barrow group was developed, most surviving examples having traces of cists or kerbs. It is probable that at this time the summit cairn was greatly enlarged and secondary cist burials were added. Most of the barrows were plundered in antiquity. The summit barrow was excavated by WC Borlase in 1879 and barrow 16073.01 was examined in 1907. Site_context_name: MCO4161: WEST COLLIFORD - Bronze Age cairn cemetery
Site_context_summary: A group of three cairns on the point of a low spur, on a slope to the west of the St Neot river; site now submerged by Colliford reservoir.
Site_context_description: A group of three cairns on the point of a low spur, on a slope to the west of the St Neot river. The area has now been submerged by Colliford reservoir. The group was located and surveyed by the OS in 1973 (h1) and subsequently marked on OS map (b1). Excavated in 1977-8, prior to flooding of the reservoir (site criv) (h2, b2). Nevertheless visible from the air in 1979 (p1) and depicted on the RCHM air photo plot (h3, b3). The cairns are all very close together and arranged in a north-south line over 50m along the spur. The northermost is the largest, having twice the diameter of the other two. Though it is nowhere specifically stated, the cross sections accompanying the excavation report suggest that the two smaller cairns (1784.2, 1784.3) had the appearance of simple turf-covered, possibly rimmed, platforms prior to excavation, while the larger (1784.1) may have been classifiable as a rimmed platform with central mound. Excavation showed in the case of the latter that the central mound was the earliest feature - a stone cairn constructed on the old land surface - with a turf stack revetted by a stone ring subsequently placed around it. It had no evidence of a burial. The two smaller cairns were simply stone kerb revetted turf mounds, but did have evidence for possible funerary rite. Cairn 1784.2 had a cist which had been emptied; in cairn 1784.3 a pit cut into the ground surface contained charcoal and some cremated human bone. Radio carbon dates for 1784.1 and 1784.3 suggest a Beaker/Early Bronze Age date. Pollen and soil analysis indicates that the cairns were constructed in an area of heather, bracken and grass dominated moorland, with an ironpan stagnopodzol - possibly the result of de-afforestation and increased grazing pressure. Finds consisted mainly of residual mesolithic flints (see 1786) but 1784.3 produced a pygmy cut with impressed cord decoration (b2).--------------------------------Site history:1: 1973. Site_context_name: MCO4089: CARADON HILL - Bronze Age cairn cemetery
Site_context_summary: A group of ten cairns set in open moorland on the SW slope of Caradon Hill.
Site_context_description: A group of ten cairns is set in open moorland on the broad, gently sloping SSW spur of Caradon Hill. Four of the cairns are marked on early OS maps (b1), and these plus one other (1411.5) were Scheduled in 1958 (h1). In 1974, the original four were re-surveyed by the OS (h2). 1411.5 was also found and surveyed; and another (1411.6) was located but not surveyed because of uncertainty about its origin. As a result, five cairns are marked on the latest OS map (b2). The RCHME aerial survey depicts the above six cairns (h4, b3) and the remaining four were discovered by Quinnell during field investigation in 1985 (h6, b4). The cairns vary in diameter from only 6.0m (1411.9) to 34m by 27m high. The majority appear to have been simple flat topped mounds, but 1411.3 and 1411.9 have dished tops which may have been an original feature; and two (1411.8, 1411.10) are tor cairns, one with a kerb and the other with a central structure, possibly a cist. The smallest and largest cairns adjoin. The majority of the cairns, particularly 1411.6 which is almost unrecognisable, have been heavily robbed, and small shelters (1421) have been built into the side of 1411.7. On the summit of Caradon Hill is a further large cairn group (1409). The cairns were plotted as part of the NMP.--------------------------------Site history:1: 1958. SAUNDERS, AD / DOE2: 1974. Site_context_name: MCO1909: CHARLESTOWN - Bronze Age barrow cemetery
Site_context_summary: The site of a group of ten barrows, all destroyed by urban development.
Site_context_description: A group of seven barrows in a line with three outliers stood on the downs near Charlestown. They were investigated in 1740 by Stephen Williams (b6) and the site has now been built upon. Two urns were found in the outliers (20341.8, 20341.9). A road was cut through some of the barrows in the early C19, and revealed a number of "British instruments" (b1, b2). A map was made of this by McLaughlin (b5).<MCO440>: An urn was found in one of the barrows investigated by Williams (b1). It was found within the outer ring of stones and was under a thin slab 1.6m across. It was made of rough earth, very hard and black inside with about 8 litres of ashes inside. It was 28cm high and 23cm wide, holding about 101. It was drawn at the time by JJ Rogers and was shown with four lugs (see illustrations in SMR); some of the sherds are said to be at Truro Museum. Note that the drawings in the SMR are confined. Both the reconstructed drawings of the vessels are of one vessel, whereas the sherds are different, ie the sherds shown in relation to 54 are from this vessel; the sherd on 53 is from another vessel and the sherd shown in 135 is different again.<MCO441>: It is said that an urn was found in the demolition of one barrow in 1801, though there was no contemporary record; later records suggest that it was found in 1805 and it seems likely that it was found in one of the other barrows on Gwallen Downs, and that it was quite different from that found by Williams in 1740 (20341.10). It was classified as a late Deverel Rimbury vessel, dated after 750 BC. It was 20cm in diameter and was decorated with dots and chevrons; some remaining sherds are in Truro Museum. When found it was said to contain about 71 fragments of human bones and ashes. See note on identity of sherds, 20341.10.

Site_context_name: Bargates, Christchurch
Site_context_summary: A multi-period site comprising Neolithic occupation, two Bronze Age ring ditches, an early Iron Age settlement, 6th/7th century cemetery and Medieval field system. Excavations during the 1970s and 1980s have revealed four main phases of occupation. Late Neolithic activity was indicated by a large pit containing grooved-ware sherds, a small circular pit and two shallow circular features. Bronze Age features include two ring ditches and a scatter of pottery to the south- west of ring ditch one. This ring ditch was totally excavated and consisted of a flat-bottomed ditch up to 0.6m. deep. Ring-ditch two was sectioned and found to be a v-shaped ditch 0.8m. deep and 2.0m. wide. No Bronze Age features were found inside either ring ditch; the pottery was of Middle Bronze Age date. Early Iron Age settlement was indicated by about 45 small pits and post-holes, and two ditches, probably representing land enclosure. No definite structures could be identified. The greater part of a pagan Anglo-Saxon cemetery of the late 6th or 7th century was discovered adjacent to the Bronze Age ring-ditches. The excavation revealed thirty graves, and four cremations in urns. The southern limit of the cemetery was located, and the cemetery thinned out to the west; the other limits were not located. The grave goods were consistent with a small settlement cemetery. After the cemetery went out of use, a medieval field system developed. A trench was extended a further 30 metres to the south-east from the 1978 excavations, but no additional Saxon inhumations were discovered. However, a complex of 12th/13th century gullies and ditches are consistent with the 1978 evidence of suburban development of the Bargates area. Watching briefs identified ditches on similar alignments to the west of the site

Site_context_name: Flagstones, Dorchester
Site_context_summary: A Late Iron Age settlement comprising the remains of a ditched enclosure, seven bell-shaped storage pits, both inside and outside the enclosure and three bowl-shaped pits. Significant quantities of Late Iron Age settlement debris were recovered from the enclosure ditch and some of the pits. Three pits also contained inhumation burials. The enclosure ditch and several pits were cut by a later ditch.
Site_context_description: Late Iron Age settlement activity was concentrated in the southern end of the excavation. It comprised a ditched field system, a ditched rectangular enclosure partially within the southern part of the excavation with a number of storage pits inside and outside the enclosure. There was also a number of burials both in pits and in graves in the same area. The full extent of the settlement is not known. It certainly continued further to the east under the garden of Max Gate (2).The pottery recovered from this settlement was almost exclusively 'Durotrigian' Black-Burnished ware jars of 1st century BC/AD date, and were probably discarded cooking vessels. Other finds included worked chalk, fired clay, worked bone objects, an iron gouge, shale and stone.Snail evidence from pit [00074] indicated this pit was dug in a grassy downland environment. Charred plant remains were found in a number of pits, including wheat and barley and a range of weeds including some arable weeds and rather more grassland weeds. Sheep/goat remains predominate over cattle and horse bones, but pig was poorly represented. Dog bones and a relatively large quantity of frog/toad bones were recovered.

Site_context_name: Alington Avenue
Site_context_summary: <MDO18529>: Evidence for an early enclosure system was discovered during excavations at Alington Avenue in the northern and eastern parts of the main site. It comprised a number of shallow, sometimes irregular ditches and gullies. Some were stratigraphically earlier than the Early Roman D-shaped enclosure or earlier than the Early Bronze Age upper fills of the long barrow ditches. They also respected the area of the Bronze Age double ring ditch suggesting that it was still extant as an earthwork and landscape feature at this time. Finds mainly consisted of flint debitage and heavily abraded early Roman pottery from the uppermost layers. Not all of the individual lengths of ditch are contemporaneous, some are cut by others but not all features can be linked into one stratigraphic sequence. The individual ditch sections do appear however, to combine to form one larger system of enclosure. Two basic phases of development of this early ditch system have been recognised. The earliest phase is composed of two main elements, a large L-shaped ditch system in the centre of the site and a smaller complex in the MW corner of the site. The overall impression is one of a system of NE-SW aligned rectilinear enclosures with a double-ditched drove running in an approximately E-W direction from the double ring-ditch along the southern boundary of the site.
Site_context_description: <MDO18529>: Found during a series of evaluations and excavations conducted by Wessex Archaeology at Alington Avenue, Fordington, Dorchester between 1984 and 1987. The results of the excavations have been published as a Dorset Natural History and Archaeological Society Monograph; (DNHAS Monograph 15). The numbers in square brackets below refer to the context and feature numbers used in the published report.The Iron Age early enclosure system comprised a number of shallow, sometimes irregular ditches and gullies. Some were stratigraphically earlier than the Early Roman D-shaped enclosure or earlier than the Early Bronze Age upper fills of the long barrow ditches. They also respected the area of the Bronze Age double ring ditch suggesting that it was still extant as an earthwork and landscape feature at this time. Finds mainly consisted of flint debitage and heavily abraded early Roman pottery from the uppermost layers. Not all of the individual lengths of ditch are contemporaneous, some are cut by others but not all features can be linked into one stratigraphic sequence. The individual ditch sections do appear however, to combine to form one larger system of enclosure. Two basic phases of development of this early ditch system have been recognised. The earliest phase is composed of two main elements, a large L-shaped ditch system in the centre of the site and a smaller complex in the MW corner of the site. The major element of this first phase of boundary ditches was a long L-shaped ditch made up of several shorter sections of ditch, which presumably formed two sides of a large enclosure, though no traces of the other sides of this postulated enclosure were found. The southern side comprised of a single length of ditch [3476] which cut the south ditch [1998] of the long barrow [2000] and terminated about 16m east of the double ring-ditch [2300]. It was fairly shallow with a rounded profile and no signs of re-cutting or cleaning out. The western side of the enclosure consisted of two lengths of ditch [3666/3679] and [2457], with two causeways or entrances between them. Ditch [3666] was oriented at right angles to [3476] with an 8m gap between them. A further ditch [2660/1948] extended at right angles to the southern end of [3666] in a NE direction with a hooked terminal at the NE end. This cut the north ditch  [1999] of long barrow [2000]. In the NW corner of the site was an L-shaped ditch [3854/3895] which appears to form two sides of a square or rectangle 14m in extant length. The eastern side of this enclosure was recut by another short length of ditch [3884].Two other sections of ditch may belong to this first phase of enclosure; ditch [4008] may represent a remodelling of the corner of the large L-shaped enclosure, and ditch [1272] which ran parallel to and about 11m south of the southern side of the enclosure.The ditches of this system were allowed to silt up before an extensive remodelling took place in the digging of new ditches which largely followed the lines of the earlier ones but with a slightly altered orientation. The southern side was formed by the roughly ESE-WNE ditch [3477/3460/3474/1263] (hereafter ditch [3474]), which turned NE just 5m away from the double ring-ditch [2300] and terminated on the line of the earlier ditch [2660]. There was an 8m wide causeway or entrance at this point and then the line of the ditch was continued to the NE by ditch [3234]. The eastern end of  ditch [3474] was cut by ditch [2850/2862/2876/1288] which presumably represents a recut. It continued eastwards out of the excavated area.About 11m south of ditch [3474] was another ditch [3209/1271] which appeared to cut the earlier ditch [1272] and was traced eastwards beyond the excavated area as a geophysical anomaly running parallel to ditch [3474].Along the western side of the site, about 40m west of the enclosure was a ditch [3865] which ran parallel to ditches [3234] and [3477] and cut across the earlier L-shaped ditch [3881/3895] in the NW corner of the site. It continued southward to stop only 8m short of ditch [1600] of the double ring-ditch [2300].The overall impression is one of a system of NE-SW aligned rectilinear enclosures with a double-ditched drove running in an approximately E-W direction from the double ring-ditch along the southern boundary of the site.

Site_context_name: Thomas Hardye School, Dorchester
Site_context_summary: During the summer of 1994 a series of archaeological excavations and watching briefs was undertaken by Wessex Archaeology, on behalf of Dorset County Council, West Dorset District Council and The Thomas Hardye School in the vicinity of Thomas Hardye School in the southwest outskirts of Dorchseter, Dorset. The site comprises three archaeological projects that were originally administered and organised separately. These projects were Thomas Hardye School Playing Fields (Wessex Archaeology ref: 37838), Thomas Hardye School Music Rooms (Wessex Archaeology ref: 39273) and West Dorset Leisure Centre Artificial Pitch (Wessex Archaeology ref: 38074). A total of approximately 4.5 ha was investigated. The site lies on a gentle south-facing slope below a low chalk ridge between Maiden Castle and the River Frome. The north of the site lies close to the top of the ridge at about the 87 m OD contour.Geophysical survey prior to the excavation had revealed a number of linear and circular features indicateive of Bronze Age ring ditches and early field boundaries. On excavation two main foci of prehistoric activity were revealed.The remains of a substantial Bronze Age linear barrow cemetery were also recorded. These comprised five barrows of which four had surviving mound deposits. The barrows and their ditches contained burials, both cremations and inhumations, indicative of a prolonged period of use and development of the barrow cemetery. Finds, particularly the large quantities of worked flint, also suggested non-ritual use of the barrows. These barrows were significant monuments in their own right and the probably also formed part of an impressive barrow cemetery ranged along a chalk ridge to the east, including Fordington Farm barrow, Conquer Barrow and the barrow central to the Flagstones enclosure.After partial excavation of the barrows, a scheme for their preservation in situ was proposed and implemented which entailed their consolidation prior to reburial beneath up to 21.5 m of chalk.

Site_context_name: Poundbury, Dorchester
Site_context_summary: A Late Iron Age unenclosed settlement was found on the slopes to the east of Poundbury Camp during excavations at Poundbury. This Late Iron Age unenclosed settlement was a continuation from the earlier Middle Iron Age settlement. The remains of five separate round houses, together with associated pits, were identified and three main phases have been defined. The earliest and latest phase had a pair of houses and the middle phase had a single large house. The earliest Late Iron Age settlement phase comprised two adjacent small round houses (IA9 and IA2) and three associated pits. Both the round houses had more than one phase of construction and repair. The second Late Iron Age phase comprised a single large round house of Pimperne type (IA4), associated with four pits. In the final phase of the Late Iron Age settlement, one large Pimperne type house and one small round house were found (IA5 and IA10 respectively), together with two pits and two scoops. An infant burial was found beneath the floor of house IA10. The economy of the settlement was entirely agricultural, with sheep/goat the most numerous animal, but in terms of potential meat contribution, cattle and horse were the main source of meat. Pig was also important. The number of sheep/goat foetuses and neonate skeletons from this settlement indicates that the animals were reared on site and not simply imported for food.  Horse may have had special significance, as shown by the apparently deliberate placing of two skulls in the weathered hollow above pit [E613]. Roe deer and small game were also present, indicating the importance of hunting. There was evidence for the cultivation of Spelt and free threshing wheat and barley, with wheat perhaps the major product of the agricultural economy. There was little artefactual evidence for the working of animal products on the settlement and almost a complete lack of metal objects.

Site_context_name: Gussage All Saints
Site_context_description: Iron Age settlement and enclosure, listed by RCHME as Gussage All Saints 20, and initially identified by air photography. The site was totally excavated in 1972, partly due to the erosion being caused by ploughing but primarily to review the evidence for Iron Age settlement provided by Bersu's 1938-9 excavation of Little Woodbury. The site was occupied throughout the second half of the 1st millennium BC and into the early decades of the Roman period. The enclosure ditch, irregular and asymmetrical, measured 120 metres north-south and 100 metres east-west internally. There appears to have been an external bank. The main entrance was to the east, and featured timber structures and was approached by "antennae" ditches which presented a funnel-like approach to the enclosure. Three main phases of occupation were identified. During the third phase, the ditch seems not to have been maintained as a physical barrier. Occupation in the first phase was represented largely by pits, post holes and some four-post structures. No round houses were identified. In the second phase, the pits and postholes were accompanied by one definite and one possible round house. The third phase saw the construction of several smaller enclosed areas, some of which may have contained timber buildings, though no clear patterning was visible among postholes and other features. The site produced a considerable assemblage of pottery from all 3 phases. Bronze and iron working occurred in all phases. An iron furnace belonging to the early Roman period was found. The most notable metalwork deposit however was from a single pit close to the site's main entrance, and dating to the 1st century BC. It comprised a large assemblage of mould and metalworking debris arising from the production of harness and chariot fittings. Remains of over 50 individuals were found, mostly from the last phase. An inhumation in a wooden coffin found just outside the main entrance was dated by pottery to the 3rd century AD.

Site_context_name: Spettisbury rings
Site_context_summary: An Iron Age hillfort on the northern end of a spur. The enclosure consists of a single rampart and ditch with an entrance on the north west. In 1972 the best preserved part of the rampart was described as standing 15 feet above the interior and 25 feet above the ditch bottom. The form of the earthworks and very limited excavation in 1958 suggest that the fort was being re-built in its later stages, and that this work was not completed. The north-eastern part of the ramparts was disturbed by construction of a railway cutting in 1857. This exposed the filling of the ditch, within which was what was interpreted as a mass grave. At least 80 skeletons were removed on this occasion, and the following year at least 40 more were removed from somewhere in the vicinity, though their exact location was not recorded. Objects recovered from the grave are said to have included iron spear-heads and sword, a bronze cauldron and bucket handles, as well as personal ornaments such as rings and brooches.

Site_context_name: Hod Hill

Parts of the interior have been ploughed in the past; finds recovered can be seen in the Durden Collection in the British Museum.  Excavations by Sir Ian Richmond (1951 to 1958) revealed a sequence of defences on the same alignment as the surviving earthworks. It had long been assumed that the ploughing of parts of the interior had destroyed or very badly damaged the remains of settlement in these areas. However, recent geophysical survey by David Stewart has revealed a detailed layout of features such as hut circles, pits and trackways throughout the fort.

This field has not been excavated.There was a thin scatter of coarse IA pottery but coins indicated that serious settlement did not take place before AD 275; of a total of 1200 coins only 18 were from Trajan to Severus Alexander.Of the area excavated the main plan consisted of a drainage system which formed rectilinear enclosures. Site_context_name: Sewerby Cottage Farm, Bridlington
Site_context_summary: <Description on On-Site Archaeology website>: During the late Iron Age much of the development area was enclosed by land boundaries, revealed throughout the evaluation and excavation programmes. In the northern excavations a square barrow and round barrow were also constructed at this time. The square barrow contained a late Iron Age inhumation and was furnished with an iron dagger and missile head. A rural farming settlement built up around the land boundaries and barrows and occupation continued until the end of the second century AD. The settlement was based around arable cultivation and livestock. Site_context_name: South Lawn, Melton
Site_context_summary: <On-Site Archaeology website summary>: The archaeological potential of the site was already known before work began on the road improvements. The lines of ditches buried beneath the crop in the arable field at South Lawn had been spotted on an aerial photograph, taken in 1976. This showed that the area north of the A63 was crossed by ditches running east to west in parallel with the modern road. They seemed to run along the side of an ancient and long forgotten trackway. This was crossed by other ditches running north to south. The layout of the ditches looked very much like other sites from the region, which are known as ladder settlements and date from the late Iron Age or early Roman period (c. 150 BC to c. 300 AD). Sites like these are important as they span the period of the Roman conquest and can tell us how the Roman occupation may have affected the lives of the people who already lived here. At Melton we had the rare opportunity to investigate the remains of a ladder settlement on a large scale. This confirmed that the site was occupied between about 100 BC and 300 AD. It also showed that the ladder settlement originated much earlier than expected. Furthermore, some elements, such as the trackway, survived for centuries, after the Roman period, until at least the seventh century AD.
